Date:  Fri, 01 Jan 2010 04:30:54 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  The IAU Minor Planet Center Guide to Minor Body Astrometry was updated again on Dec 18, 2009
The IAU Minor Planet Center Guide to Minor Body Astrometry was updated again on Dec 18, 2009.
It was updated earlier on Dec 11 as noted by J05 P. Birtwhistle.

http://www.cfa.harvard.edu//iau/info/Astrometry.html

The link to the Dec 18 change points to "When should I use a discovery asterisk?"
The link to the Dec 11 change points to "What about coverage on a single night?" 

Date:  Sat, 02 Jan 2010 22:17:54 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Soho comet
Hello

We had no bright comet on the night sky. But we could see now
a very bright Kreutz on Web.
I will post a animation soon, taken 35 Soho images
jan 1 UT 14.42 to jan 2 UT 21.18

To see it you need Quck Time Player

Michael

From:  Gustavo Muler

81P wild, 02-01-2010

http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/81/81-100102-J47.jpg 

Date:  Tue, 05 Jan 2010 20:10:00 -0000
From:  Gustavo Muler 
Subject:  127P/Holt-Olmstead, 04-01-2010
http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/127/127%20-100103-J47.jpg

faint image of a comet. 127P eat the small east, and was testing the new
configuration of the telescope.
did not accompany the night much, but it was nice, but with high clouds.
the comma reaches ten seconds of arc, from what I measured.
a greeting!
gustavo.

imagen de un cometa dbil. el 127P pequea coma al este, y fue probando la
nueva configuracion del telescopio.
la noche no acompaaba mucho, pero fue agradable, aunque con nubes altas.
la coma llega a diez segundos de arco, segun lo que he medido.
un saludo !
gustavo.

Date:  Thu, 07 Jan 2010 08:47:51 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  comet 232P/Hill with its thin tail (image of January, 5 2010)
Hi comet friends,

except of 81P and C/2007 Q3 there are less "bright" comets on the sky.
But the weak comets are my special friends.
Here is a new image of 232P/Hill alias P/2009 W1 (Hill) with a thin tail of
55" in PA 283.
Short after the detection of the comet at November, 19 2009 some observers
already reported this tail in IAUC 9095.

More informations of the comet at:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/232p.htm

Details of the image:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/232p_20100105.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/ 

Date:  Thu, 07 Jan 2010 12:31:43 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  comet 47P/Ashbrook-Jackson with its short tail (image of January, 2 2010)
Hi all,

Another very faint comet:
47P/Ashbrook-Jackson with a short tail of 11" in PA 130.

More informations of the comet at:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/47p.htm

Details of the image:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/47p_20100102.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/ 

Date:  Fri, 08 Jan 2010 21:45:26 +0100
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  New images and old archived images
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi list,

I have updated the image gallery of the german comet section.
http://kometen.fg-vds.de/bildere.htm

There are also some very old images of comets 1P/Halley, 1989r
Okazaki-Levy-Rudenko and 1975n West.

Thanks to Juergen Linder for scanning the old images.

Please let me know what you think about these old images. Unfortunately
the data of the images are only in German. But they are quite old.

- --
Regards,

Stefan Beck

"All comet observers of the world"
http://www.cometchaser.de/observers/names.html
http://www.cometchaser.de/observers/map.html

http://www.cometchaser.de
"Astrophotography with small telescopes"

http://www.cometchaser.de/d_index.html
"Astrophotography with small telescopes auf Deutsch"

From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2007 Q3 Siding Spring 08-01-2010
You have posted some terrific comet images today Gustavo
C/2007 Q3 seems to me to be the most active right now and fun to image.

This image suggests more curvature in tail.

Wish I could figure out how to calculate the beta angle and associated parameters for synchrones. Will just have to keep working on that.

Hi all,

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a1_20100113.htm

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/232p_20100113.htm

New navigation structure of my homepage:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/periodical_comets.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/non_periodical_comets.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/asteroids.htm

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/index.htm

Clear skies and better weather
Bernhard Haeusler

Date:  Thu, 21 Jan 2010 05:21:04 -0000
From:  Tony 
Subject:  Comet 17P Holmes
I was digging around in a folder on the web server and found a few fits of 17P taken during the outburst that never got around to being processed. Taken with GRAS G2 blue filter

I could not find any darks to calibrate them but there is still alot of data there.
http://img124.yfrog.com/img124/7238/8dst.jpg

I colorized it to bring out the detail in the coma and surrounding the nucleus
http://img162.yfrog.com/img162/5811/xgc.jpg

Tony

Date:  Tue, 02 Feb 2010 10:59:05 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: [comets-ml] New HST image of comet P/2010 A2 (LINEAR) on Jan 29, 2010 shows X-pattern at coma head location
I agree....but what is more incredible is trying to come up with some physical explanation
for the morphology that we see in this object.
Very difficult to diagnose or even speculate; the symmetry of the structure seems to
eliminate rotational effect and the uniformity of the "jets" along the primary axis is
very puzzling.

Dr. Clay
_____
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 02 Feb 2010 21:36:54 +0100
From:  Danilo Pivato 
Subject:  Review of 46 photos about Comet: C/1995 O1 Hale-Bopp
Hi all,

I recovered from my personal archive old analog shots of Comet Hale-Bopp,

which date from the period of maximum brightness (February-May 1997).

Each shot was made simultaneously with 4 (sometimes 5)

objective lenses of varying focal length and film.

Each film has been passed in a high-resolution scanner, requiring many

months of work, having made 32 passages in multi-exposure.

Now each original is available with a resolution of 10854x8760pixel 16-bit.

Regards

Danilo Pivato

http://www.danilopivato.com/solar_system/comets/c1995_O1_hale_bopp/c1995_O1_hale_bopp.htm

MySiteWeb: http://www.danilopivato.com 

Date:  Tue, 02 Feb 2010 21:43:40 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet C/2007 Q3
Hello Charles,
the few comets that has shown Sodium signatures were all much close to the Sun.
Cherrs,
Giovanni

Jose.

On 02/02/10 21:36, "Danilo Pivato" wrote:

> Hi all,
>
> I recovered from my personal archive old analog shots of Comet Hale-Bopp,
>
> which date from the period of maximum brightness (February-May 1997).
>
> Each shot was made simultaneously with 4 (sometimes 5)
>
> objective lenses of varying focal length and film.
>
> Each film has been passed in a high-resolution scanner, requiring many
>
> months of work, having made 32 passages in multi-exposure.
>
> Now each original is available with a resolution of 10854x8760pixel 16-bit.
>
> Regards
>
> Danilo Pivato
>
> http://www.danilopivato.com/solar_system/comets/c1995_O1_hale_bopp/c1995_O1_ha
> le_bopp.htm
>
> MySiteWeb: http://www.danilopivato.com
>
> ------------------------------------
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
> 

Date:  Tue, 02 Feb 2010 16:57:14 -0800

You are right.
C/2007 Q3 is on its way out now

Date:  Thu, 04 Feb 2010 14:36:16 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Review of 46 photos about Comet: C/1995 O1 Hale-Bopp
Well Done! Your hard work has paid off. I remember going out each morning to get the east sky on the other side of a small town and gathering hundreds of negative shots using only a 35mm SLR manual camera and tri-pod. For todays standards they would not be considered much but man was I excited at the time after the negatives were processed and there was that wonderfull comet changing all the time.
Mike

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Danilo Pivato" wrote:
>
> Hi all,
>
> I recovered from my personal archive old analog shots of Comet Hale-Bopp,
>
> which date from the period of maximum brightness (February-May 1997).
>
> Each shot was made simultaneously with 4 (sometimes 5)
>
> objective lenses of varying focal length and film.
>
> Each film has been passed in a high-resolution scanner, requiring many
>
> months of work, having made 32 passages in multi-exposure.
>
> Now each original is available with a resolution of 10854x8760pixel 16-bit.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 06 Feb 2010 05:36:47 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] color image of comet 29P
Very nice images of 29P being posted here by all.
Thank you. I have been clouded out for so long.

All the latest images show the coma or what we see of the tail extending to the east (left in most images) I could easily have this backwards.

29P is currently at 6.192 AU and its solar radial distance is increasing.
Its phase angle is also very small at 0.9 degrees and getting very small.
So it is pointing almost directly away from earth and we are seeing the tail end of this comet.

This is a very large distance for a comet to be experiencing such a large transition in activity.

I am wondering why and whether it has done this before at the same time in its orbit.

I am not so familiar with its past history as others are.

Seiichi Yoshida's light curves may help us answer our questions.

http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/0029P/2004.html

The distance that this comet is doing this at may be associated with one particular volatile material.
I don't know which one (or more) that might be. A spectroscopic analysis would help very much.

What are you all thinking about this comet?

I am such a neophyte to comets. All I know to do is say something and hope someone will correct me.

I know no other way to learn. I want to learn what the images are trying to tell us. There are so many intelligent people posting here. Help me out. Thank you.

Charles H47

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47
Comets and Asteroids on Facebook: http://bit.ly/chE2M1

________________________________

Rolando Ligustri

Date:  Sun, 07 Feb 2010 14:30:48 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  29P Schwassmann-Wachmann outburst Feb 6, 2010
Hello all,

My visual observation of comet 29P in outburst last night.

29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 1
2010 Feb. 6.54 UT: m1=10.8, Dia.=0.5', DC=8...20cm L 57x...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)

ICQ format
2010 Feb 6.54, 10.8, 0.5' (M.Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria,
Australia,20cm reflector);

This is my brightest observed outburst of 29P. The comet appears as a bright
circular disk, much like a planetary nebula. It is currently 5.2AU from
Earth and 6.2AU from Sun.

Find images on my website at:

http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo

Date:  Mon, 08 Feb 2010 23:05:33 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of P/2010 A2 (LINEAR) on February, 07 2010
Hi all,

the asteroid collision is leaving back a thin dust structure with some knots
meanwhile.
Images: 80 minutes exposure (16 x 5min.). 2010-02-07 UT 22:27 12"SCT f-5.65
+ CCD ST10XME, field of view: 30' x 20'.

One image frozen on the dust structure, the other image frozen on stars and
dust structure.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a2_20100207.htm

Clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn 

Date:  Tue, 09 Feb 2010 01:24:03 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: image of P/2010 A2 (LINEAR) on February, 07 2010

Mike

Date:  Tue, 09 Feb 2010 16:44:51 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  C/2007 N3 (Lulin) still with a tail of 9 arc minutes
Hi all,

like on my image of December, 18 2009 the comet has a weak tail of around 9
arc minutes.
The central condensation with its coma has only 18.16 mag in a 10" x 10"
box.

Image of February, 07 2010:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20100207.htm

here my image of December,18 2009:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20091218.htm

CS
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Thu, 18 Feb 2010 08:44:31 -0000
From:  Tony 
Subject:  Re: 81P Wild 2
I live in Okinawa Japan and the weather here is cloudy at least 90% of the year. I had planned on building an my own observatory but only being able to use a few nights a year put an end to that. So I do everything by remote mostly with GRAS. With GRAS I can control the telescope over the internet using ACP control panel, it is very easy to use. if you want to try gras for free you can get a trial account with $100 in points here. Their support is great if you ever have a problem or something happened you get to talk with owner of the company, Arnie is very hands on guy.

http://global-rent-a-scope.com/trial/

Tony

Subject:  C/2009 K5 McNaught
This comet is rising in our morning skies, and is probably worth a shot or two with better gear than mine. Did a rough widefield this morning, and K5 shows up as a nice, green, bright little comet.

First link is C/2009 K5 cropped from a stack of 12 30-sec subs. Second shows current proximity to Nova Scuti 2009.

Date:  Fri, 19 Feb 2010 03:08:57 -0000
From:  Freddy W 
Subject:  Comet images capture and stacking
I have a hard time stacking Comet images with DSS.
I have to admit that the comet 29P is rather quite dim in a 120s ISO1600 taken with a C14" scope captured with a Canon 40D and Focal Reducer f 6.3.
Is it better to use a 128mm f/9 Meade Refractor Canon 40D and focal Reducer ?
I usually use DSS for that, before I did not had any problems with stacking on stars and Comet. But with these faint buggers it does not work all the time.
Just your opinion guys.
There are a few nice brighter comets coming up so I do not want to mis them.
Freddy 

Date:  Fri, 19 Feb 2010 00:11:58 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet images capture and stacking
I am not sure what DSS abbreviation you are referring to.
Deep Sky Survey??

I use Astrometrica for stacks of moving objects such as comets and asteroids. You have to know the focal length of your imaging train and the pixel size and some idea of the orientation your image. Once you can get that program to do plate solutions on your images, it will stack them based upon the object motion. Its the best program I know of. The feature is called Track and Stack. It will bring out faint objects that you can not see in single frames.
It does require either FITS or SBIG images to work.

There are lots of ways to convert images to FITS format, such as ImageJ, a free image processing program.

I don't know much about Canon cameras, but if you can bin your images you can perhaps go deeper. I have a Nikon D50. It has various resolution selections. I think that by using a medium resolution instead of the maximum, you may be able to see fainter comets.

If you can cool your imaging chip down, that helps out quite a bit.

The other option is to change focal ratio to a faster/lower ratio such as F/3.3

Do you have the internal aperture of your camera fully open? I had to use a toothpick to manually jack my Nikon camera aperture full open.

You get features such as these standard with a SBIG camera. There are many other CCD cameras, that may be better suitable for imaging faint comets. I think they use the term Lux rating, with the lower the better. Monochrome over color.

Of course guiding to get a long exposure is generally preferrable.

Charles

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47
Comets and Asteroids on Facebook: http://bit.ly/chE2M1

________________________________
From: Freddy W
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thu, February 18, 2010 9:08:57 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet images capture and stacking

I have a hard time stacking Comet images with DSS.
I have to admit that the comet 29P is rather quite dim in a 120s ISO1600 taken with a C14" scope captured with a Canon 40D and Focal Reducer f 6.3.
Is it better to use a 128mm f/9 Meade Refractor Canon 40D and focal Reducer ?
I usually use DSS for that, before I did not had any problems with stacking on stars and Comet. But with these faint buggers it does not work all the time.
Just your opinion guys.
There are a few nice brighter comets coming up so I do not want to mis them.
Freddy

Date:  Fri, 19 Feb 2010 08:34:03 -0000
From:  Freddy W 
Subject:  Re: Comet images capture and stacking
Thanks Charles for the explanation.
DSS is the program Deep Sky Stacker and normally it works well on stacking bright comets and other deep sky objects.

I will look into that.

Thanks
Freddy

Date:  Sun, 21 Feb 2010 20:55:37 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Comet observations and images Feb 19, 2010
Hello all,

Herewith my visual comet observations for Feb 19th 2010.

29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 1
2010 Feb. 19.61 UT: m1=10.6, Dia.=1.5', DC=5...20cm L 57x...Michael
Mattiazzo (Castlemaine, Victoria)
[coma appears as a bright circular haze of high surface brightness]
ICQ format
2010 Feb 19.61, 10.6, 1.5' (M.Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria,
Australia,20cm reflector);

81P Wild 2
2010 Feb. 19.62 UT: m1=9.6, Dia.=3', DC=6...20cm L 57x...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
[First observation. Bright starlike nucleus with a hint of tail in PA 290]
ICQ format
2010 Feb 19.62, 9.6, 3' (M.Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, Australia,20cm
reflector);

Find images of these comets on my website at:

http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo 

Date:  Sun, 21 Feb 2010 13:45:11 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /michael jaeger/2007Q320100221UT219s7x240we.jpg
Uploaded by : schmidtcamera2500
Description : 2007Q3 2010-02-21 UT 2.19 8"/2.8 SXV-H9 L-7x240 RGB 3x120 sec M.Jger

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/2007Q320100221UT219s7x240we.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/forms/general.htmlfiles

Regards,

schmidtcamera2500 

Date:  Sun, 21 Feb 2010 13:50:22 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /michael jaeger/2009O220100221UT348s3x150.tif
Uploaded by : schmidtcamera2500
Description : 2009 O2 Catalina 2010-02-21 UT 3.48 8"/2.8 SXV-H99 3x150sec M.Jger

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/2009O220100221UT348s3x150.tif

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/forms/general.htmlfiles

schmidtcamera2500 

Date:  Sun, 21 Feb 2010 07:46:22 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
C/2009 O2 (Catalina) is in a very dense star field just like 118P is right now.
The MPC ephemeris shows it growing in elongation rapidly over the next several weeks and gaining brightness by almost 2 magnitudes. Perihelion in about 4 weeks with a highly eccentric orbit.

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47
Comets and Asteroids on Facebook: http://bit.ly/chE2M1

Date:  Wed, 24 Feb 2010 20:49:48 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  image 81P and C/2007 Q3 of 24/02
Hello,

New color image image of comet C/2007 Q3 (Siding Springs) + 81P/Wild of 24
febr. 2010
taken remotely Tzec Maun - near NM skies
single shot of 600 sec.

C/2007 Q3
http://tiny.cc/grjqJ

81 P
http://tiny.cc/1e5Pm

Date:  Thu, 25 Feb 2010 11:03:02 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Nice shots! Good to see C/2009 K5 at a larger scale, and C/2006 W3 rising in morning skies again. 65P Gunn is reasonably high in morning skies now from AU and should be brightening - it might be a good target for you. Not far from Nunki in Sagittarius at the moment. Keep up the good work!

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
http://robsastropics.googlepages.com/comets

Martin

night here.

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2009u3_20100304_mpm.jpg

Date:  Fri, 05 Mar 2010 16:12:49 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comets - 03/05/2010 - C/2007 Q3, C/2009 O2, 81P and 10P maybe
Hello. The skys started off good early, too bad the comets were later. Started with 81P. Changed cameras to the much weaker ST2000xm because of the bad conditions, wind, smoke frome fires somewhere and Moonlight. Should be really nice comet in a week or so.
http://fototime.com/DD69B0E44F3FFFE/orig.jpg
Slew to the north for C/2007 Q3. Once again should be nice in a week or two.
http://fototime.com/651DAC95AB06DF4/orig.jpg
Next I went to the eastern horizion and found this small comet. C/2009 O2. I hoped for more but these days I take what I can get.
http://fototime.com/862EFF656E2807D/orig.jpg
Last comes what might not even be the comet. I took 9x90 second images. Stacked them 3 different ways, blinked anywhere from 2 to 9 at a time for movement, inverted, enlarged and other things I don't remember and saw nothing except this image which shows a structure at the correct place. It is an average of all 9 images with a stack on the stars. I have my doubts but will post it anyway.
http://fototime.com/6419C951647A9F2/orig.jpg

Hope others have good skys soon.
Mike H. 

Date:  Fri, 05 Mar 2010 17:31:37 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Comets - 03/05/2010 - C/2007 Q3, C/2009 O2, 81P and 10P maybe
> Last comes what might not even be the comet.

We imaged it the other night:
http://bit.ly/aJgHS0
Currently the comet is at (about) magn. 18, with no obvious signs of coma and/or tail.
Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero

Mike

Date:  Mon, 08 Mar 2010 04:36:25 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  29P - 2010/03/08
Hello. This is a color taken just an hour ago. 4x3min for lum and 1x3min each for rgb. Skys cleared for a while before the next storm arrives tonight. The small galaxy below and right is PGC 26627 listed by guide at 16.5 mag. Not sure what galaxy cluster is just above but the nearest is A 795 with a magnitude of 17.5. Would like to have more clear times.
TV127is refractor
ST10 xmei ccd
FR - 540mm at F4.2
UV/IR block filters

Thanks
Mike H.

http://fototime.com/76D9160B8137CA4/orig.jpg

Date:  Fri, 12 Mar 2010 14:47:09 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  tail of C/2007 N3 (Lulin) is still active
Hi all,

you can still see a tail of some arc minutes (max. 15) on my last images of
the comet from December 18 2009 to March, 11 2010. The central condensation
has a magnitude of 18.5 meanwhile.

Is there anybody who can confirm this tail. Who has any idea, which kind of
tail we see on the images?

Details on:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20100311.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20100307.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20100207.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20091218.htm

Overview on the Lulin site:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3.htm

Clear skies
Bernhrad Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/index.htm 

Date:  Fri, 12 Mar 2010 23:57:31 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  P/2010 A2 with a constant sunward directed dust structure, 37 arc sec in PA 278 on March, 11 2010
Dear comet experts,

P/2010 A2 is still having a very constant dust structure since two months.
The structure is directed towards the Sun from the point of view of the
asteroid since weeks.

Newest image and detailled informations on this site:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a2_20100311.htm

Overview of P/2010 A2 on:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a2.htm

Can anybody explain the geometry of the structure, please.
How strong is the influence of the Solar wind to the structure?

Clear skies and best greetings
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/index.htm

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/81P_WILD.html
direct link C/2007 Q3
http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/C2007_Q3.html

Date:  Fri, 19 Mar 2010 21:15:30 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  C/2007 Q3 (Siding Springs) of 19/03
Hello,

Here an image of comet C/2007 Q3 taken with remote telescope.
http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/menu.html

This image let see a possible split of the nucleos of comet C/2007 Q3, like
first mentioned by Nick Howes who has taken an image with the 2.0-m Faulkes
telescope.

Date:  Sat, 20 Mar 2010 18:22:42 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Re: Small Refractor Question
Hi Mike,

I am also in the market for a 60 mm imaging scope. My choice so far is the Takahashi FS-60CB
http://www.optcorp.com/product.aspx?pid=2179&kw=FS-60CB&st=2

I prefer it to the TeleVue because with the reducer the Tak is f/4.5. That is 1.8 times faster. I prefer fast scopes, and my Takahashi Epsilon is f/3.3.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL

Hello,

another faint comet behind the Jupiter orbit, but with a nice short tail:

Date:  Sun, 21 Mar 2010 15:27:24 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Re: Small Refractor Question
Hi Mike,

The reducer is $420 -- Tak accessories are very pricey! Scroll down here
http://www.optcorp.com/product.aspx?pid=2179&tb=5&kw=FS-60CB&st=2

Best bet is to call OPT about fitting your camera. They have a knowledgeable staff and it is easy to get connected to a real human when you call them.

Let me know which one you get. I want my 60 mm for my Canon DSLR as all of the Canon lenses I've tried have unacceptable abberations.

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Sun, 21 Mar 2010 19:00:57 -0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Color image of Comet SW 1 taken friday night...
Hi all,

Im glad to post my first comet image here, with our new 8" f/4 astrograph:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/SW1-031810/sw031810.html

I could not easily see the comet visually, but the 5 min test shot put it right in the middle. This is a one hour exposure.

Chris Schur
Payson, Arizona 

Date:  Sun, 21 Mar 2010 15:15:06 -0400
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Color image of Comet SW 1 taken friday night...
Really nice Chris. Sure reminds me of 17P/Holmes.
Bob

a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

Description : 2009 O2 Catalina 2010 march 24 UT 2.58 8"/2.8 15x75 sec Sigma 6303 Michael Jger

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/2009O220100324UT258s15x75.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/forms/general.htmlfiles

From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Small Refractor Question
Dennis. I have the TV 60is on the way. Found a couple of used 60c tak's but in the end I could have the TV new with much less in the way of extentions, tubes and rings for attaching The f6 should not be much of a problem with the ST10xmei. In the future I think an 11000 chip would be nice. Now we need some clear skys.
Mike

> >
> > Best bet is to call OPT about fitting your camera. They have a knowledgeable staff and it is easy to get connected to a real human when you call them.
> >
> > Let me know which one you get. I want my 60 mm for my Canon DSLR as all of the Canon lenses I've tried have unacceptable abberations.

Date:  Fri, 26 Mar 2010 10:21:35 -0000
From:  Burkhard

Burkhard Leitner 

Date:  Fri, 26 Mar 2010 04:33:18 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  C/2009 K5 (McNaught) March 14, 2010 1128UT
C/2009 K5 (McNaught) March 14, 2010 1128UT

http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/4432607015/in/photostream/

Comet is now approximately 5 weeks before perihelion (T 2010 Apr. 30.0194 TT with q = 1.422371 AU )

Coma is growing in size and brightening, and sky motion of this comet is increasing daily as it nears both the earth and sun.

Its phase angle (sun-comet-earth angle) is also increasing giving us a better view.

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47
Comets and Asteroids on Facebook: http://bit.ly/chE2M1 

Date:  Fri, 26 Mar 2010 04:44:00 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  81P/Wild on March 15, 2010 1004UT
81P/Wild on March 15, 2010 1004UT

http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/4436008440/in/photostream/

This comet is currently a month past perihelion (T 2010 Feb. 22.7042 TT)

Its been terrific.

Its earth distance or delta is still decreasing. Its sky motion is very slow at 0.17 arc sec/minute, allowing longer exposures.

Now is the time to be shooting wide fields of this comet, since the tail is very long.

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47
Comets and Asteroids on Facebook: http://bit.ly/chE2M1

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2010 07:46:06 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] my album of comets
> Dear Rolando,
> Wow, wow and more wow! Thanks for sharing your page with us. So nice to see
> the daylight Comet McNaught again.

Hi Bob, I remember this incredible comet !
I ran away from work for being able to photograph...
arrive at the observatory, while the bells rang at noon
and see it in the finder just 6 degrees from the Sun was for me a great emotion!

I added the photo was made by putting a small digicam to C11 ;-)))

best regards
Rolando

image
> Dear Rolando,
> Wow, wow and more wow! Thanks for sharing your page with us. So nice to
see
> the daylight Comet McNaught again.
> Bob

a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/p2010e2_20100313.jpg

http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/forms/general.htmlfiles

Date:  Sun, 28 Mar 2010 08:54:36 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  www.cometpieces.at
Hello

28 years ago I shot my first comet.
On my homepage, I present a number of recordings from this period comets
but also current material.

One focus is to show comet images from the 80s and 90s.
I request your understanding that this site is under construction.
>From time to time, the archive is expanded.

www.cometpieces.at

Michael Jäger 

Date:  Sun, 28 Mar 2010 18:34:04 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  image C/2007 Q3 of 27 march
Hello,

New image image of comet C/2007 Q3 (Siding Springs) of 27 march 2010
taken remotely Tzec Maun - near NM skies

images on:
http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/menu.html

or direct link:
http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/C2007_Q3.html

______________________________________________

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck - Belgium

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/
BRIXIIS privat observatory - MPC code: B96
coordinates: 418.6 E - 519.8 N
______________________________________________
C.A.R.A. - Cometary ARchive for Amateur astronomers -
http://www.cara-project.org
VVS - Vereniging voor Sterrenkunde - http://www.vvs.be
Antares - http://www.astrobasis.be/

Dear friends of comets

Thank you for the many words of praise. These old recordings are unique. It would be a shame if they were lost.

Hello,

a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File :
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/1008062323/pic/704003545/view?picmode=&mode=tn&order=ordinal&start=21&count=20&dir=asc

Description : 81P/Wild 20100325 - 12"Newton f/4.8 - ST-10 XME - 20x30s
- tail: 8' PA: 277deg - Irmtraut - Josef Mueller A21

File :
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/1008062323/pic/546149614/view?picmode=&mode=tn&order=ordinal&start=41&count=20&dir=asc

Description : C/2007 Q3 (Siding-Spring) - 12" Newton f/4.8 - ST-10 XME -

Date:  Fri, 02 Apr 2010 12:11:34 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  P/2010 A2 (LINEAR) on April, 1 2010
Hello all,

the dust/debris structure is still constant, 1'03" in PA 286.5

details of the image of April, 1 under:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a2_20100401.htm

summary of the last three months:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a2.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler (amateur)
B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/index.htm

Date:  Sat, 03 Apr 2010 21:52:09 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Comet Machholz new image
Hi

This evening i found the comet a second time.

http://www.cometpieces.at/images/phocagallery/2010f420100403lrgbut1855web.jpg

April 3, UT 18.55, 8"/2.8 L-18x30 sec RGB 30/30/30 bin 2x2, SXV-H9

It is not brighter than 10m0/5. Today i could see a short tail to pa 290°

Michael 

Date:  Sun, 04 Apr 2010 03:43:21 +0200
From:  "M. Gembec" 
Subject:  81P/Wild
Hello

I think this is now the best comet on the sky. We have seen not only
oval shaped coma, but also some tail to the right. When I took images
through Celestron ED80/600, I saw, that the tail is longer than I
expected. Maybe more than 1 degree (53' on my photo).

And see this contrast enhanced image, there is some green in coma -
maybe ions CO+ or what? So this dusty comet maybe has green coma too!

Images are taken with Canon 30D modified at ISO 800, 6x4min exposure.

Martin Gembec
Czech Republic

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 04 Apr 2010 03:50:18 +0200
From:  "M. Gembec" 
Subject:  81P - images
Sorry, I didn't know about sending e-mail without images. So they are
in Comet-Images Files section in Martin Gembec folder.

MaG 

Date:  Sun, 04 Apr 2010 09:43:15 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  my latest color image of comet 81P
http://picasaweb.google.it/astroligu/CometeDiRolandoLigustriCASTItalia#5456184036685390786

best regards
Rolando Ligustri

Date:  Sun, 04 Apr 2010 11:50:51 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  Re: 81P/Wild
Nice shots Martin! I imaged 81P a couple of weeks ago with an unmodded, unfiltered DSLR and a lemony-green colour was very evident. These cameras respond well to blue-green. The image is very poor and wasn't worth posting, but here's a link anyway just to show the colour:

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/81P10Mar2010textc.jpg

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
http://sites.google.com/site/robsastropics/comets

Date:  Mon, 05 Apr 2010 10:34:13 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  Image of C/2010 F4 Machholz in the murk
I managed a very noisy shot of Machholz yesterday evening
from the UK. Altitude 9 degrees, Sun -11 degrees.
Solar elong 25 degrees.
It's not a pretty sight, but was at least recorded, in the centre
of the image.

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2010f4_20100404_mpm.jpg

Comets page:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html

Regards,
Martin

Date:  Tue, 06 Apr 2010 04:14:24 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  New comet C/2010 G1 (?), image on April, 5 2010
Hi all,

this ist my first image of the new comet.
Measurements with Focas II:
10x10 20x20 30x30 40x40 50x50 60x60
SNR SB COD
OBJECT DATE TIME +/- +/- +/- +/- +/- +/-
N FWHM CAT
------------ ---------- -------- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----
---- ---- ---
RG14C6D 05/04/2010 20:17:10 15.88 14.95 14.47 14.15 13.92 13.73
6.7 18.0 B82
RG14C6D 05/04/2010 20:17:10* 0.05 0.04 0.04 0.07 0.07 0.09
7 4.8 CMC

IAUC Message is still not here, so I don't know the discoverer.

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2010g1_20100405.htm

Date:  Fri, 09 Apr 2010 14:41:59 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  10P Animation - 04/09/2010
This was tough with my setup. I can say the position and time are good in guide. Info - refractor 5" F4.2 - 530mm - clear ir/uv filter - 5x120 se exp - enlarged 2.3x - n/up. One non-star labeled - about 1130ut.
http://fototime.com/0C20217E4AAD235/orig.gif

Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Fri, 09 Apr 2010 11:00:46 -0500

Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 10P Animation - 04/09/2010

the blink, all in the same direction.

Clay

Dr. Clay

Date:  Fri, 09 Apr 2010 19:53:11 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  81P - 04/09/2010
Hello. This image from 04/09/2010 at around 1000ut. Contains 6x120 sec images with a median combine because of all the sats. 5" TV127is using a clear ir/uv filter and an ST10xmei. FR made it 530mm at F4.2.
Thanks.
Mike H.

http://fototime.com/E06718C8BAA0502/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 09 Apr 2010 20:35:58 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 - 04/09/2010
3x30 second images make this bad image. Only object showing where guide shows it to be. No way for me to tell excepy DSS images don't show any bright objects. It was getting light fast.
Thanks, Mike H

http://fototime.com/C2A1C11BCA3E038/orig.jpg

Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /Lovejoy/c2009r1.jpg
Uploaded by : terryjlovejoy
Description : C/2009 R1 - April 6.78, 2010

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Lovejoy/c2009r1.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/forms/general.htmlfiles

terryjlovejoy 

Date:  Sat, 10 Apr 2010 00:23:36 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 - April 6.78, 2010
See image of C/2009 R1 from April 6 which was made in relatively poor conditions.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Lovejoy/c2009r1.jpg

Details:
Observer: T.Lovejoy
Site: E27 (Thornlands)
When: April 6.78 UT (mid exposure)
Scope: 20cm f2.1
Camera: QHY9 (image binned 2x2)
Orientation: North at top
Exposure: 3 x 60 sec.

Terry

From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /Registered Stack-1.zip
Uploaded by : algwat
Description : Wild 81P and other object., need help to ident other mover. rgds Alan.

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Registered%20Stack-1.zip

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/forms/general.htmlfiles

Regards,

algwat

Date:  Sat, 10 Apr 2010 18:52:49 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comets-04/10/2010-First Light TV60is
Hello. Fired up the TV60is with my ST10xmei ccd for first images using the TV127is for a guide scope. Imaged 3 comets before 00:00ut with 81P sitting low still.
Thanks, Mike H.

29P-5x2min-ST10xmei-TV60is-cropped from 2150pix wide to about 1600-1x1 bin-04102010
http://fototime.com/AFF1F98FEFA8719/orig.jpg

81P-3x4min-ST10xmei ccd-TV60is-1x1 bin-cropped-04102010
http://fototime.com/C397EC7D5E692E2/orig.jpg

C/2007 Q3-5x2min-ST10xmei-TV60is-cropped-1x1bin-04102010
http://fototime.com/D70B54A0BA0D5D7/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 10 Apr 2010 13:55:52 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comets-04/10/2010-First Light TV60is
Very nice images Mike; I see that you got the same satellite tracks through that of 81P
that I had to put up with for about an hour. Busy section of sky.
Looks like the refractor is going to produce good results.

Dr. Clay
_____
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Sun, 11 Apr 2010 04:11:58 -0000
From:  Tony 
Subject:  Re: Comet 81P Wild 2

Right now for Global Rent a Scope is running a $100 free trial during the Global Astronomy Month.

http://global-rent-a-scope.com/Trial/

The scope is 100% controlled by you. if you want to see how to image comets with your trial account take a look at this page

http://astronomy.fm/forum/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=489

Tony

Date:  Sun, 11 Apr 2010 17:07:58 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  NEO or Satellite? the complete story.
Hi all,

a report for interested guys.
On April, 7 I followed a "possible NEO" more than an hour.
The object came into my field of view, when I took images of comet P/2010 A2
(LINEAR).
Finally an Atlas Centaur upper stage was identified.

See you and good luck
Bernhard Haeusler

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/1973058B.htm

Is the image of C/2007 Q3 in full resolution and 1:1 as we see on the
webpage ?
I think the pixelresolution of your setup must be smaller to see the
secundary fragment of C/2007 Q3.

Date:  Tue, 13 Apr 2010 00:02:12 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 McNaught, 12 April 2010
Rough image of C/2009 R1 from this morning. Seems brighter than ephemeris, but maybe not quite as bright as the recent report of mag 10.2. Will be interesting to see what happens as it's predicted to reach naked-eye brightness. NHem unfortunately for me, hope you all enjoy it, LOL!

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/R112Apr2010text.jpg

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
http://sites.google.com/site/robsastropics/comets 

Date:  Tue, 13 Apr 2010 00:35:38 -0000

http://img6.imageshack.us/img6/3231/k3j.jpg

Tony 

Date:  Tue, 13 Apr 2010 07:32:16 +0200
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2009 R1 McNaught, 12 April 2010
Rob, thanks for posting. Interesting widefield image.

Regarding my recent ( Apr. 10.20 UT ) estimate at m1=10.2, is
necessary to remember the differences between digital photometry (
CCD/CMOS/... ) and visual magnitude estimates, some of them resulting
from the different spectral regions observed by the sensor and the
dark-adapted human eye.

In any case, we must wait and see ... hoping that the brightening
trend continues.

Best regards and clear skies,

J. J. Gonzalez

-------------------------------------------------------

Date:  Tue, 13 Apr 2010 13:04:00 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  Re: C/2009 R1 McNaught, 12 April 2010
Thanks Juan, that's true, and not only that, I had the comet in low skies with a bit of variable murk. I only decided to give it a shot after reading your obs, and I'm glad that I did (even if the final result wasn't exactly a work of art!).

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman

Date:  Wed, 14 Apr 2010 23:41:59 +0200
From:  Josef Müller 
Subject:  C/2008 FK75 (Lemmon-Siding Spring)
Comet C/2008 FK75 (Lemmon-Siding Spring)
at 4,45 AE (666 449 522 km) form our planet!
Perihel in autumn 2010; now mag 17.5
Tail! and PA!
http://www.westerwald-astro.de/jjm/kometen/c2008fk75-lemmon-siding_spring_hp.php?BackPath=kometen
photo croped and invers:
http://www.westerwald-astro.de/jjm/kometen/c2008fk75lemmon-siding_spring_invers_hp.php?BackPath=kometen
Hope you all enjoy it!
Cheers Josef Mueller A21

Date:  Thu, 15 Apr 2010 17:47:44 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Color photo of 81P Wild, April 15
A wide field image of 81P from this morning.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/Com135A52ED.jpg
130mm f/4.9 TMB with ST8300 C CCD, 180 seconds.
First shot that I have been able to get without equatorial satellites getting in the way.

Clay

Date:  Fri, 16 Apr 2010 15:01:14 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  P/2010 A2 (LINEAR) on April, 7 2010
Hi all,

the shape of the dust/debris is still constant with 47" in PA290.
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a2_20100407.htm

During the series of images of P/2010 A2, the Atlas Centaur upper stage
1973-058B crossed the image.
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/1973058B.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Sat, 17 Apr 2010 09:02:52 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  Close conjunction coming up
C/2009 O2 Catalina & C/2010 G1 Boattini will get as close as 9 arcminutes apart (8'50"?) at around April 18.7 UT, according to my planetarium program. Too low in late twilight for me to get unfortunately.

Cheers -

Rob

- 81P Wild 2

Alfons Diepvens 

Date:  Sat, 17 Apr 2010 13:34:51 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  04F0011 object: elongated shape
Dear All,

last night I managed to image this object, remotely using
the main instruments of the Virtual Telescope Project and
taking benefit from the usual good seeing at that location
(last night it was 1.9", typical values are 1.7/1.8").

Image scale is 0.62"/pixel.

The image is here:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/04f011_16apr2010b.jpg

I used 120 seconds of exposure; you can see its unusual
shape, with a profile definitely different from that of a
star. It is worth to note that the elongation is in a very
different PA than the motion of the object (E-W).

Best,
Gianluca

Date:  Sun, 18 Apr 2010 04:49:54 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  development of P/2010 H2 in 24 hours
Hello,

the comet is 0.3 mag brighter in 24 hours (10 x 10 box). The shape is
clearly oval (19" x 24").
A very faint coma of around 1 arc minute is visible in stacked images of 30
x 2 min. exp. time.

More details on:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010h2_20100418.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2010 07:53:12 -0000
From:  riklaunim13 
Subject:  81P at 20.04.2010
I've imaged 81P tonight once more. DMK21, 11,554 sec exposure, more than 100
frames, red filter (RGB) passing red + IR, 150/750 Newtonian. 20.04.2010 00:57:46 Poland, Warszawa

Stack on comet
http://www.rkastrofoto.appspot.com/site_media/astro/orig/comet81p-20-04-2010/zps.png
raw stack:

http://www.rkastrofoto.appspot.com/site_media/astro/orig/comet81p-20-04-2010/1ps2.png

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2010 11:59:59 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  images of comet P/2010 H2 (VALES) on April 19 + 20, development of brightness
Hi all,

the brightness of the comet had its temporary peak at April, 19.
The wide coma is corresponding to the inner oval shaped coma and reached its
maximum range on April 19 with 3'36" * 2'49" on the stacked image (30 * 2
min. exp. time).

here is the development in 10 x 10 arcsec box (FOCAS II):

April, 17.1: 12.47 mag
April, 18.1: 12.19 mag
April, 19.1: 12.01 mag
April, 20.1: 12.42 mag

Details with animations on this site:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010h2.htm

images of April 19 + 20:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010h2_20100419.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010h2_20100420.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2010 14:49:22 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  Image of P/2010 H2 Vales via GRAS New Mexico
An image of the new comet Vales, taken remotely via
GRAS New Mexico, a few hours ago, has been uploaded to
my website. Comet is dead centre; slightly elongated coma.

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2010h2_20100420_mpm.jpg

Comets page:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2010 10:34:43 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Central condensation in c2010 H2
I obtained some images under very steady skies this morning of Comet Vales (2010 H2);
longer exposures reveal the concentration and seemingly uniform makeup of the elongated
coma, but shorter exposures corrected for the density of the core, reveal a 15th magnitude
nucleus:

http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/Com1360847B.jpg

If this link does not work correctly, please go to the ASO home page
http://www.arksky.org/
and click on the "Comet Data" menu selection.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2010 20:17:45 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of P/2010 A2 (LINEAR) on April, 17 2010, passing star cluster NGC 2420
Hi all,

the dust/debris structure is still very constant: 43" in PA 288.
Under good conditions it should be no problem to get the structure on long
term exposures.
Has anybody new images, too?

Summary of all observations since January:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a2.htm

last image of April, 17 together with NGC 2420:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2010a2_20100417.htm

See you and clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Thu, 22 Apr 2010 15:31:12 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Fwd:MACE 2010: One month to go!
Forwarding a notice about an interesting meeting...
Cheers,
Giovanni

***************************************************

Dear asteroid/comet/meteor enthusiasts,

the time flies and summer is near. Only one month to go until the
MACE 2010 weekend (May 21-23) in Visnjan/Croatia (IAU code 120).
The vulcano on Iceland returned to sleep and air traffic should have
normalized very soon. We look forward to an interesting and pleasurable
conference with pro/am participants from many countries.

The webpage now has the talks that were submitted until today.
If you intend to give a talk, please submit the necessary information
as soon as possible (see webpage for details).

The Palazzo Sincic was booked as meeting venue (See a 3D picture of it
on the webpage). There is room for 60-80 participants. Please do register
as soon as possible to ensure your place at MACE2010.
We can't guarantee admission for participants who arrive to the conference
without prior registration if we hit the limit!

If you haven't booked an accomodation yet, we are happy to announce that
we were able to negotiate the availability of the special rates for the rooms
in and around Visnjan until Apr. 30.

MACE 2010 webpage:
http://www.minorplanets.org/MACE2010/

Don't miss this great opportunity. Who knows when the next one will be! :-)

>From Visnjan/Croatia on behalf of the
Astronomical Society of Visnjan, Yours truly,
Reiner M. Stoss

Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] P/2010 H2 (Vales) of the 2010.04.21
John,
Use the new Minor Planet Center site at

http://www.minorplanetcenter.org/iau/mpc.html
You will find the latest elements link in the left side panel under Orbital
Elements - Orbital Elements for Programs.

Regards,
Colin Drescher
Brisbane, Australia

Date:  Sun, 25 Apr 2010 14:01:19 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  Comet or Asteroid? the storyboard of my observation of 04NB001
Hi all,

on April,24 04NB001 was posted to the NEO confirmation page.
Here is the storyboard of my observation of the object:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/04nb001.htm

details of this morning:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/04nb001_20100425.htm

At least Tim Spahr of the MPC told me, even bigger telescopes couldn't
confirm activity.
The object is determined to be a normal Minor Planet.

CS Bernd Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Sun, 25 Apr 2010 19:28:35 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  back from Namibia
Hi everybody,

I recently returned from our trip to Namibia, where I installed the first
ASA DDM 85 mount on the southern hemisphere. The mount, as well as an ASA
12" Astrograph, is housed in the observatory at Farm Tivoli.

I had the opportunity to image with this equipment over a period of 13
nights under excellent sky conditions.

I already uploaded some images of the equipment to give you a feeling:

http://www.astrostudio.at/namibia.php

The first image I´ve processed is one of comet 81P/Wild2. The comet ideally
was located at the zenith at midnight. Because the comet moved very fast,
processing was a challenge as always.

http://tinyurl.com/3y9uspw

Hope you like it. Thanks for looking. Tipp: Toggle your F 11 tab to close
browser tool bars.

regards

Gerald

Date:  Mon, 26 Apr 2010 17:00:34 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  comet C/2009 R1 Mc Naught
Hello,

I thought it could be on interest for this list to post my observations of
comet C/2009 R1 Mc Naught taken in Namibia.

The first image was taken on April 13th UT 3h28m with 12" f 3.6. Elongated
coma is approx 2-3´.

http://tinyurl.com/39dk2hx

The second image was taken on April 20th UT 4h03m with 12" f6.8 (barlow):

http://tinyurl.com/32h8l2b

Estimated magnitude is 10.5

Zodiacal Light was very bright

regards

Gerald

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  images and trilogy of the last outburst from April, 16 to April, 18 2010
Hi all,

here are the images of April, 16 to April, 18 2010:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/29p_20100416.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/29p_20100417.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/29p_20100418.htm

Here is the animation and description of the three days, showing the
development of the outburst:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/29p_20100416to18.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

From:  tricks46 
Subject:  P/2009 H2 - 2010/05/04
Hello. Interesting shell like structures now showing on my images. I am currently taking a group of 10 minute exposures to better show just how many are there. Hard to tell with small refractor. Also want to make sure comet is sitting next to a star that I can't find in guide.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/C7F94E7DAF394AD/orig.jpg

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/artnovich/9p_20100504.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/forms/general.htmlfiles

Regards,

artnovich

Date:  Wed, 05 May 2010 02:02:33 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: P/2009 H2 - 2010/05/04
Hello. I have spent a few hours processing and gathering new images. I found that more exposure was not an answer as it allowed the fainter stuff to fill in between the spirals. I did take some 180 sec exposures and combined 3 for this image. The comet has moved off the star and this is just about as good as it is going to get for the 4th of May with my software.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/93D66599D5EAF00/orig.jpg

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Please consider this post to be for P/2010 H2 not P/2009 H2. I really should proof read
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
> >
> > Hello. Interesting shell like structures now showing on my images. I am currently taking a group of 10 minute exposures to better show just how many are there. Hard to tell with small refractor. Also want to make sure comet is sitting next to a star that I can't find in guide.
> > Thanks, Mike H.
> >
> > http://fototime.com/C7F94E7DAF394AD/orig.jpg
> >
>

Date:  Thu, 06 May 2010 16:52:46 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet P/2010 H2 Vales imaged this morning at H47 May 6, 2010 0440UT Tail developing 2 arc minutes at PA 120
Comet P/2010 H2 Vales imaged this morning at H47 May 6, 2010 0440UT Tail developing 2 arc minutes at PA 120

http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/4584852041/

I still see the elongation in the condensed portion of the coma in the north east/southwest but an extended coma is developing to the south east..

Best wishes,

Charles Bell H47

Date:  Tue, 11 May 2010 15:53:25 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Developing jets, extension on C/2009 K5
As reported by others, we captured two very fine eastward-facing jets or extensions on
comet McNaught 2009 K5. The comet is beginning to lose some of its spherical symmetry and
now elongating eastward.
Image posted at the ASO Comet Archives:
http://www.arksky.org/php/cdata.php?object=c/2009xxxK5xxx(McNaught)

photo direct link: http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/Com137C208B.jpg

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Fri, 14 May 2010 01:10:39 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  10P Tempel badly
Managed to get something of 10P the other night under difficult conditions of haze & low altitude (had to throw most of the subs away). Seems to be somewhat brighter than ephemeris predictions. The DSS overlay was done to confirm that this was actually the comet - the ephemeris position marked with a cross was generated in AAVSO's Variable Star Plotter.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/10P12May2010composite.jpg

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
http://sites.google.com/site/robsastropics/comets

Date:  Tue, 18 May 2010 13:07:11 -0000
From:  msdeprest 
Subject:  Re: Comet Vales Saturday night....
Great shot Chris,
I was up in northern lower Michigan on saturday night ... and with my 18" f/4.5 at an extremely dark site and near perfect seeing and transparency thies was an fairly easy target. You captured it just as I noted it. Thank you for posting your results ... I am writing a little article for our club's newletter and would like to use your image in the article (with your permission and credit of course), do you have any objections?

Thank you again
Mark S Deprest 

Date:  Tue, 18 May 2010 14:40:04 -0000

From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Wild 2 in Virgo
HI all,

This 9th magnitude object also in Virgo boasts a degree long tail, and a greenish coma. Certainly the best comet currently in the evening sky!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/xtiastro/wild2051810.html

Date:  Wed, 26 May 2010 07:49:21 +0200
From:  francois Kugel 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2009 R1 from this morning 2010-05-25.11
Hello Burkhard,
FOV of this picture is around 25'x75'.
Instrument is a 0.5-m F/3 +ccd kai 11k. (full size = 1°x1.5°)
The tail is probably longer than 1.5°

From:  walcom77 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 (McNaught) with Disconnection Event
Hi All

Today, in our images of comet C/2009 R1 (McNaught) is clearly visible
a nice disconnection event (DE) in the plasma tail of the comet.

Here you can see the images:

http://bit.ly/dpUi2d

http://bit.ly/cTHeVn

Ernesto Guido and Giovanni Sostero
http://remanzacco.blogspot.com

Date:  Sun, 30 May 2010 09:00:44 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 15th image of C/2009 R1 (McNaught)
Appears to have possible faint ion tail disconnection event at center of this image.

There may be disconnection events associated with recent solar activity.

>From the Report of Solar-Geophysical Activity issued: 2010 May 28 2200 UTC,
There was a solar Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) event May 23- 24, 2010. An interplanetary shock was observed at the ACE spacecraft May 28, 2010 at 0203 UTC
Boulder magnetometer observed a 33 nT sudden impulse May 28, 2010 at 0259 UTC, the activity is most likely due to the arrival of the CME observed on May 23, 2010
http://www.swpc.noaa.gov/

Thanks to everyone for posting and sharing your images.

Charles

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47
Comets and Asteroids on Facebook: http://bit.ly/chE2M1

________________________________

Date:  Tue, 01 Jun 2010 22:08:04 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  C/2009 K5
It is approximately magnitude 8.9 and has a broad diffuse fan tail extending about 10 arc minutes as imaged under a full moon. My images and supporting data are here
http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
and I hope you will take a look.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

5-5-2010

OBS Marius Duran
MEA Marius Duran
TEL 0.3-m f/4.46 Newtonian reflector
AC2 m.duran@modiprot.com
ACK C12_2010_06_05-1

NET CMC-14

CK09R010 C2010 06 05.13105 01 53 59.98 +38 58 39.6 09.3 N C12

Date:  Sun, 06 Jun 2010 19:18:52 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 at hig resolution - 6 June 2010
Dear All,

this is an image of this comet at hi-res (0.62"/pixel), where the comet
shows a nice tail and some possible structures close to the nucleus
(after applying a 15deg rotational gradient):

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/C2009r1_6june2010.jpg

regards,
Gianluca Masi 

Date:  Sun, 06 Jun 2010 23:47:03 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  10P Tempel, 6 June 2010
Imaged this comet last night (unfiltered DSLR, 200mm, 8 x 90 sec) - nice green comet, diffuse coma extending faintly to perhaps 10 arcminutes or more diameter, elongated in approx PA 300 deg.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/10P6June10filttextb.jpg

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
http://sites.google.com/site/robsastropics/comets

Date:  Tue, 08 Jun 2010 13:44:27 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Re: about this marvelous R1 - THANK YOU ALL.
Dear Colleagues

I thank you all for your interest in my comet images.
After two months of almost constant bad weather, the weather has changed. From Austria, it is possible to track the comet from now to
around june 24. Next week it will be necessary to go to high mountain locations.

Therefore it is possible that I can not immediately update my homepage after june 13.

best regards
Michael Jäger

Date:  Wed, 09 Jun 2010 15:30:45 -0000

Date:  Wed, 09 Jun 2010 16:07:43 -0000
From:  jdilapo 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 (McNaught) crossing NGC 891
On June 8th. about 2:00 AM Eastern time (USA), I imaged Comet McNaught, with my friend Mike, as it was passing in front of the well known, edge-on galaxy NGC 891. With the moon rising at 2:40 AM and the comet only 10 degrees above the horizon (and partially blocked by the observatory roof) it was a real challenge to get the shot ... and, not to mention fighting the clouds! We used a 12" SCT with a SBIG ST9-E camera and 15 seconds subs.
Here's a very preliminary short stack of the comet crossing NGC 891. We hope to get the fully processed color image completed soon:

http://www.tinyurl.com/dilapo-mcnaught

And the inverted image:

http://www.tinyurl.com/dilapo-mcnaught-inverse

Regards,

Tristan and Mike 

Date:  Wed, 09 Jun 2010 19:26:13 -0700

Date:  Fri, 11 Jun 2010 17:56:03 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2009 R1: some shell structure visible?
Dear all,

I processed this image of comet McNaught, grabbed on Jun 9
2010 while the sky was significantly bright. It *seems* to
show some hints of a shell structure, a sort of arc in the
Sun direction.

This is an uncertain detail, as there is not enough signal
and there is noise because of the bright sky to firmly
conclude, but I would like to ask other observers to check
their images. Likely, it is not real, but it would be nice
to give it a try.

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/C2009r1_9june2010ls.jpg

regards,
Gianluca Masi 

Date:  Fri, 11 Jun 2010 18:32:35 -0000

Hello!

I've done two images of R1

2. Singleshot 300s B&W
http://www.schweifstern.de/images/comets/r1/r1-5min-crop-50proz.jpg

Date:  Sun, 13 Jun 2010 08:25:30 -0700
From:  FRANK GUTOWSKI 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2009 R1 (McNaught) crossing NGC 891
Hi Tristan and Mike,

--- On Wed, 6/9/10, jdilapo wrote:

From: jdilapo
Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2009 R1 (McNaught) crossing NGC 891
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, June 9, 2010, 12:07 PM

On June 8th. about 2:00 AM Eastern time (USA), I imaged Comet McNaught, with my friend Mike, as it was passing in front of the well known, edge-on galaxy NGC 891. With the moon rising at 2:40 AM and the comet only 10 degrees above the horizon (and partially blocked by the observatory roof) it was a real challenge to get the shot ... and, not to mention fighting the clouds! We used a 12" SCT with a SBIG ST9-E camera and 15 seconds subs.
Here's a very preliminary short stack of the comet crossing NGC 891. We hope to get the fully processed color image completed soon:

http://www.tinyurl.com/dilapo-mcnaught

And the inverted image:

http://www.tinyurl.com/dilapo-mcnaught-inverse

Regards,

Tristan and Mike

Date:  Mon, 14 Jun 2010 19:04:42 -0000
From:  TomP 
Subject:  Which Tail Is The Ion Tail?
Here are my images from three nights.

http://www.pbase.com/polakis/image/125536296

I thought that the ion tail is the stubby one that has a similar color as the coma, but I have been told otherwise on another forum. Is the short tail really the dust tail? Thanks.

Tom 

Date:  Mon, 14 Jun 2010 21:32:10 -0000
From:  cbellh47 
Subject:  Re: Which Tail Is The Ion Tail?
The dust tail is the short stubby one on comet C/2009 R1(McNaught)
The ion tail is the long thin one, which extends in anti solar direction

Sometimes the dust tail is referred to as the "antitail" which can be confusing (at least to me).

Wikipedia is a nice quick reference:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comet#Coma_and_tail

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "TomP" wrote:
>
> Here are my images from three nights.
>
> http://www.pbase.com/polakis/image/125536296
>
> I thought that the ion tail is the stubby one that has a similar color as the coma, but I have been told otherwise on another forum. Is the short tail really the dust tail? Thanks.
>
> Tom
> 

Date:  Mon, 14 Jun 2010 16:56:39 -0500
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Which Tail Is The Ion Tail?
Hi Tom and everyone,
I also figured the short one was the dust tail, but it's interesting
that this dust tail glows green like the coma instead of white/pale
yellow. Is it contaminated with cyanogen?
Thanks
Bob

Date:  Mon, 14 Jun 2010 17:10:58 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2009 R1 - 2010/06/13
This is a stunning image.

The ion tail appears to be thinning out as the comet moves further away from the ecliptic.

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 15 Jun 2010 00:15:44 -0000
From:  TomP 
Subject:  Re: Which Tail Is The Ion Tail?


OK. I just aligned a straight-edge with the long tail, and that arrow points in line with the sun, as an ion tail should The stubby dust tail projects well to the north of the sun. Thanks.

Tom

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Bob King wrote:
>
> Hi Tom and everyone,
> I also figured the short one was the dust tail, but it's interesting
> that this dust tail glows green like the coma instead of white/pale
> yellow. Is it contaminated with cyanogen?
> Thanks
> Bob
>

Date:  Tue, 15 Jun 2010 00:19:24 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Which Tail Is The Ion Tail?
Good work. That's the way to do it.

Supposedly, there is a small deviation angle which averages about 3 degrees from the solar direction attributed to aberration. I have never seen anyone measure it here that I remember. Ludwig Biermann figured that out from his comet study in 1951.
Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47
Comets and Asteroids on Facebook: http://bit.ly/chE2M1

________________________________

Tom

Date:  Tue, 15 Jun 2010 17:12:43 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  2009 R1 june 6 reworked
Hello

Bad weather over Central Europe prevents further observations of the comet. Therefore I had time to rework the image from June 6.
The comet was at this point in outburst.
Seven images were used.

June 6, 00:05 UT L-4x170 and 3x210 sec 8"/2.8 and CCD SXV-9

http://www.cometpieces.at/images/phocagallery/2009r120100606web.jpg

Best regards
Michael Jäger 

Date:  Tue, 15 Jun 2010 10:52:56 -0700
From:  FRANK GUTOWSKI 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2009 R1 june 6 reworked

I must say that this is a very beautiful image that you put together. Thanks.

Frank

> From: schmidtcamera2500
> Subject: [Comet-Images] 2009 R1 June 6 reworked
> To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
> Date: Tuesday, June 15, 2010, 1:12 PM
>
> Hello
>
> Bad weather over Central Europe prevents further observations of the comet. Therefore I had time to rework the image from June 6.
> The comet was at this point in outburst.
> Seven images were used.
>
> June 6, 00:05 UT L-4x170 and 3x210 sec 8"/2.8 and CDC XXV-9
>
> http://www.cometpieces.at/images/phocagallery/2009r120100606web.jpg
>
> Best regards
> Michael Jäger

Date:  Wed, 16 Jun 2010 21:17:49 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 - 13th Again
Hello. I took 5x180 second images and put them together with some different software. I normally only use this when combining images using the DSLR on nonmoving objects. Reduced from 2150 pix wide to 1650.
Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 17 Jun 2010 11:21:11 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  27th image of C/2009 R1 (McNaught)
Uploaded my 27th shot and first UK based shot of C/2009 R1.
Comet approx 11 degrees altitude in the permanent UK
summer twilight.

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2009r1_20100616_mpm.jpg

Regards,
Martin

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html 

Date:  Thu, 17 Jun 2010 13:57:27 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 - 2010/06/17
Hello. It was cloudy with the passing high kind so this is all the info I took less one frame with and aircraft passing directly over the comet false nuk. the 3.6 mag star shows the seeing as time went by and the spikes got longer as the comet got higher. This is a 29x180 combination
Thanks
Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/A5046AFFC67A5C3/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 17 Jun 2010 14:25:19 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  2009R1 jun 16/17
Hello

Contrary to all weather forecasts, I could watch last night the comet.
The trip went into the alps. At 1700 meters above sea level prevailed perfect conditions. Thick fog blocked off the lights from the valley. For voltage caused in the night a herd of cows who are interested in my telescope and laptop.
The comet: I couldn't see it by naked eye. Mc Naught is not brighter than 5m2. Thus, the comet has remained stagnant since June 6 in brightness. During this period the coma have substantially reduced.

The image (with Leica-Apo f-180/4.5) showed 2009 R1 about the Dachstein
on june 16 UT 22.50
L-3x360 sec
RGB 120/120/120

http://www.cometpieces.at/images/phocagallery/2009r120100616ut2255web2.jpg

Best regards
Michael Jäger 

Date:  Thu, 17 Jun 2010 17:04:43 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2009R1 jun 16/17
Superb!

regards
Rolando

----- Original Message -----
From: "schmidtcamera2500"
To:
Sent: Thursday, June 17, 2010 4:25 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2009R1 jun 16/17

Hello

Contrary to all weather forecasts, I could watch last night the comet.
The trip went into the alps. At 1700 meters above sea level prevailed perfect
conditions. Thick fog blocked off the lights from the valley. For voltage caused in
the night a herd of cows who are interested in my telescope and laptop.
The comet: I couldn't see it by naked eye. Mc Naught is not brighter than 5m2. Thus,
the comet has remained stagnant since June 6 in brightness. During this period the
coma have substantially reduced.

The image (with Leica-Apo f-180/4.5) showed 2009 R1 about the Dachstein
on june 16 UT 22.50
L-3x360 sec
RGB 120/120/120

http://www.cometpieces.at/images/phocagallery/2009r120100616ut2255web2.jpg

Best regards
Michael Jger

Date:  Thu, 17 Jun 2010 19:28:17 +0200
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2009R1 jun 16/17
> http://www.cometpieces.at/images/phocagallery/2009r120100616ut2255web2.jpg

Superb! But the question remains: Why is the stubby dust tail as green as
the coma? Same happens in the APOD today -
http://apod.nasa.gov/apod/ap100617.html - where for unknown reasons the
color of the ion tail was 'tuned' to grey. If you put the cursor onto the
picture, all the stars disappear ...

Dan

Michael

Date:  Thu, 17 Jun 2010 19:44:23 -0000
From:  emartincz 
Subject:  C/2009 R1 (McNaught) 2010-06-15
Hi all, I have processed now my image from June 15th, when comet was passing by Mellote 20 in Perseus constellation. It has nice and long blue ion tail and interesting green "dust" tail.
Image taken with Canon 30D modified + Canon 70-200/2.8L (f3.5/200mm) at ISO1600 (12x1min exp).

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/obraz/foto/comet/c2009r1/c2009r1_20100615_12x1min1600iso_200mm-50p.jpg

Martin Gembec
Czech Republic

Date:  Sat, 19 Jun 2010 10:04:17 -0000
From:  sunblack74 
Subject:  Comet R1 McNaught 19june2010 (DSLR)
Location hills 78kg far from Rome (IT).
Frames shooted between 3.15h and 3.30h LT.
Canon 7D + Nikon 180/2.8 @ f/4 8x1m 800iso; please note the open cluster on the right.

Bonus: The comet in the twilight (22.53h LT) 2° high. Canon 7D + Nikon 180/2.8 @ f/4 single 30s 400iso

http://img710.imageshack.us/img710/2681/8xrawresflatstarsweb.jpg

http://img192.imageshack.us/img192/1384/img8902aweb.jpg

Date:  Mon, 21 Jun 2010 10:21:09 +0200
From:  "J.P.Navarro Pina" 
Subject:  update light visual curve of comet C/2009 K5 McNaught
Hi all ,

Update the light visual curve of comet C/2009 K5 McNaught , based in 79 magnitudes visuals from ICQ and lists of yahoogroups.com observadorescometas and CometObs , the comet show the brightness constant for range -30 and + 60 days from T ( -30< days from T < +60 ) , and range magnitude ( 8.0 < m1 < 8.5 ) , the totals paratemers photometricals calculateds , absolute magnitudes m0 = +5.9 and , activity index n = 3.7 .
Graphic here :

http://webs.ono.com/jpab

Regards ,
J.P.Navarro Pina .

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 21 Jun 2010 17:43:30 +0000
From:  Michael Büchner 
Subject:  Comet McNaughtt R1 from 19.06.2010
Hello,

on a short trip to Provence in France I made the following photograph of the comet.

http://www.sternfreundefranken.de/php/view.php?pid=203

Instrument:
TBM 105/650mm; TMB Field Flattener; SBIG ST10 XME, L= je1X120sec
Left image was taken at: 03:28 MESZ, the right one at 04:01 MESZ

Regards
Mike

Date:  Thu, 24 Jun 2010 19:23:18 +0200
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] little video of comet R1
> Hi at all, this are two little video of the comet C/2009 R1
>
> http://comete.uai.it/comete/animazione1.gif
> http://comete.uai.it/comete/animazione2.gif

Wonder- as well as colorful! But one question: Why does Pi Aurigae - the
upper one of the two bright stars to the left of the comet - look exactly
as bright as Beta Aurigae (the lower one) although it is 2 1/2 mag. dimmer
(4.3 vs. 1.9 mag.)?

In binoculars - I observed with 11x70 from Germany at the same time - the
great brightness difference was obvious. The comet's very condensed coma,
by the way, at times looked almost as bright as Pi Aur, though when dawn
got brighter, it looked fainter again (and most recent estimates had it at
~5.3 mag. anyway).

Dan 

Date:  Thu, 24 Jun 2010 17:34:08 +0000
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] little video of comet R1
Beautiful pictures Rolando!

I have the same question as Dan, I saw the comet last night and Pi Aur
was definitely fainter than Beta!

Albert

Date:  Thu, 24 Jun 2010 20:03:08 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] little video of comet R1
Hi Dan, Hi Albert
I used an very old Canon lens that has a lot of chromaticism!
This leads to very dilated stars, once 'played' levels the two stars are of equal
size :-)

cheers
Rolando

PS: sorry for my terrible English

Date:  Fri, 25 Jun 2010 20:23:47 +0900
From:  Masayuki Suzuki 
Subject:  Re: little video of comet R1
Beautiful pictures!

Spectral type might influence too.
Spectral type of pi Aur is M.
M star through the unfiltered CCD looks brighter than visual
because it emits strong infrared light.

Clear skies
Masayuki

----- Original Message -----
From: "ligustri rolando"
To:
Sent: Friday, June 25, 2010 3:03 AM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] little video of comet R1

> Hi Dan, Hi Albert
> I used an very old Canon lens that has a lot of chromaticism!
> This leads to very dilated stars, once 'played' levels the two stars are of equal
> size :-)
>
> cheers
> Rolando
>
> PS: sorry for my terrible English
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From:
> To:
> Sent: Thursday, June 24, 2010 7:23 PM
> Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] little video of comet R1
>
>>> Hi at all, this are two little video of the comet C/2009 R1
>>>
>>> http://comete.uai.it/comete/animazione1.gif
>>> http://comete.uai.it/comete/animazione2.gif
>>
>> Wonder- as well as colorful! But one question: Why does Pi Aurigae - the
>> upper one of the two bright stars to the left of the comet - look exactly
>> as bright as Beta Aurigae (the lower one) although it is 2 1/2 mag. dimmer
>> (4.3 vs. 1.9 mag.)?
>>
>> In binoculars - I observed with 11x70 from Germany at the same time - the
>> great brightness difference was obvious. The comet's very condensed coma,
>> by the way, at times looked almost as bright as Pi Aur, though when dawn
>> got brighter, it looked fainter again (and most recent estimates had it at
>> ~5.3 mag. anyway).
>>
>> Dan
> 

Date:  Fri, 25 Jun 2010 15:15:35 -0000
From:  Waldemar 
Subject:  Comet R1 June 24
Hello

hard to image comet R1... 9° above horizon, nearly full moon, townlights and upcoming dawn.

Here is an RGB 120x3 crop with 4° landscape field
Comet R1 240610 0048UT

http://www.schweifstern.de/images/comets/r1/r1_2406100048-rgb120s_4fov.jpg

and BW inverted version

http://www.schweifstern.de/images/comets/r1/r1_2406100048-rgb120s_4fov_bw-inv.jpg

Greetings
Waldemar

Date:  Mon, 05 Jul 2010 16:20:50 +0200
From:  "J.P.Navarro Pina" 
Subject:  ANALYSIS COMET C/2009  R1 MCNAUGHT
Hi all ,

Analysis update for the light visual curve of comet C/2009 R1 McNaught , based in the recopilation of 114 magnitudes visuals from ICQ , CometObs , and observadorescometas yahoogroups.com , the last m1 is for date 25/6/2010 , and the possible discovery for 2 outburts based in my personal analysis for this light visual curve for this comet , graphic and analysis here :

http://webs.ono.com/jpab

Regards , J.P.Navarro Pina
Murcia , Spain .
