Date:  Wed, 07 Jul 2010 19:34:54 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  103P
Hello. I know we were, for the most part, hoping for a good show from R1 and some may consider it a nice object but this comet just sat in a bad location. A lot of us lost a lot of sleep trying to image this one through the trees. Michael J's amazing images will be recorded as the best of all for history and are well deserved IMO. Now I look to the future. Will 103P be a good comet? Can someone compair it to a past comet for imaging considering the new improvments in equipment? Will it be a 8P type or M4 surprise. Guess it doesn't make much difference for me as the clouds are just overpowering for a long time now but I look for the members to supply my comet images needs. Any thoughts are welcome if you don't mind.
Mike H. 

Date:  Thu, 08 Jul 2010 13:00:12 +0200
From:  Alfons Diepvens 
Subject:  NEW images  6-7 July 2010  :  C2008 FK75 / C2007 Q3 / 10P / 103P / C2009 UG89


NEW images 6-7 July 2010

- C2008 FK75 Lemmon- Siding-Spring
- C2007 Q3 Siding-Spring
- 10P Tempel
- 103P Hartley
- C2009 UG89 Lemmon

with a direct link to the image:
http://users.telenet.be/diepvens/cometimages/index.html

Alfons Diepvens 

Date:  Thu, 08 Jul 2010 12:48:32 -0000
From:  Jakub 
Subject:  Re: 103P
Hello Mike,
with 103P, my estimate is, that it wont be some extraordinary show.
This comet usually have only tiny ion tail, and close approaching suggest it would have big and diffuse coma.

About surprising, nucleus of this comet is very small and its water production indicates 100% active surface, which is very high exception between comets. So its hardly to imagine, it can show higher activity then past returns.

Still high activity of nucleus indicates strong central condensation and easy look. I guess it owuld be typical big coma gasseous comet with small, tiny tail.

Still the geometry and location of comet at sky indicates very good conditions for best view of it!

Best regards,
Jakub Cerny

Date:  Sun, 13 Jun 2010 18:03:00 +0200
From:  "J.P.Navarro Pina" 
Subject:  Update light visual curve of comet C/2009 R1 McNaught
Hi all ,

New and updating the light visual curve pre-perihelion of comet C/2009 R1 McNaught , based in analysis differential of 121 magnitudes visuals from ICQ , CometObs , and observadorescometas , show three different's laws photometricals , this new analysis confirm the discovery of 2 outburts before perihelion , and confirm brakes the brightness ~ 20 days from T , about m1 maxima ~ +5.0 , this brake is probably change of volatils domains
CO + > H2O typicals from news comets of Oort Cloud .

http://webs.ono.com/jpab

Regards , J.P.Navarro Pina .

Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 10P Tempel 2 Dust trail 2010 July 20
Hello Albert,
yes there are many trace of satellites, the fine line trought the
comet is the Dust trail.
I will send now a mosaic of this dust trail from this morning.
Francois

Date:  Wed, 21 Jul 2010 12:00:26 +0200
From:  francois Kugel 
Subject:  10P/Tempel 2 dust trail : 10° long from this morning 2010-07-21


Hello,
After the discovery of the dust trail of comet 10P/Tempel 2 from July 14,
I planned to imaging it along his orbit :
Here you can find a mosaic of 8 images (9x60s each, no filter);
the dust trail on this image is around 10 long towards west,
and probably longer, but daylight was coming soon.

http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/images/cometes_img/10P/mosa025.jpg

skymap including images (Prism sofware) :
http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/images/cometes_img/10P/fusprism-img.jpg

More images of 10P : http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/pages/10P.html

Francois Kugel, C. Rinner
#A77

Date:  Sun, 01 Aug 2010 15:42:15 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  images and animation of C/2007 Q3 (Siding Spring)  July, 31 2010   B82 Maidbronn
Hola and hi,

last night I found the comet with its dust tail and a thin tail of 23'in
PA264.
Here you find some images, frozen on comet, stars and ddp image processing.

Also an animation of 30 frames.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007q3_20100731.htm

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007q3_20100731_details.htm

Overview:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007q3.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

Date:  Fri, 06 Aug 2010 00:10:19 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Group Information
Hello All.
I have been in contact with Elizabeth Warner about the posting of images once again as some of us did for Deap Impact mission. I know some already know of this so please excuse any duplication this might cover. I will just post the reply I received today. I personally enjoyed the last mission and hope to help with images for Epoxi mission.
Thanks for your time
Mike H

"Hi Mike,

Hey, great to hear from you!!

Yes, we will be collecting images once again for the Amateur Observers'
Program. I need to update the website.

The URL will be aop.astro.umd.edu

The submissions will be manual, not exactly automated like we had for
Deep Impact (no longer have access to the server and database
functionality)...

We are also collecting the images on the Facebook page at
http://www.facebook.com/EPOXI...

Clear Skies!
Elizabeth Warner
warnerem@astro.umd.edu
301-405-6555"

PS - After 2 weeks of temperatures of 106F and higher, it is raining outside! WOOHOO

Date:  Sat, 14 Aug 2010 08:46:28 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet Encke and M104 on 30 August
Hi,

I'm just looking at the path of Comet Encke over the next few months and note that Encke will be about 20' to the SW of M104 (Sombrero Galaxy) on the 30th August (17h UT). No good for me in NZ (it's -25* elevation at morning twilight), but someone on this round planet may get to image it...

Some other occurrences -
5th Sept, 01h UT, 16' NNE of mag 11.7 galaxy NGC 5054.
6th Sept, 20h UT, 13; NNE of mag 12 galaxy NGC 5170.

Note that these are worked out for my New Zealand position, but they should give some guidelines for possible photo opportunities...

Cheers

John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Thu, 19 Aug 2010 20:08:10 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet Encke imaged tonight
Hi all,

please find attached an image of Comet Encke (2P) imaged about 8 degrees above the western horizon tonight (about an hour ago) - 2010 August 19, 0700 hrs UT. I imaged it with a 41cm (16") Meade Newtonian @ f5,2 and 450D DSLR @ 1600asa. 12 x 30 second exposures. North is roughly up and East is roughly left. It's nice to see this comet again.

Hopefully Yahoo doesn't strip the image from this email...

Cheers

John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287

Date:  Sat, 21 Aug 2010 18:33:38 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Re: 10P, 103P and 219P 20100821
Hello Jean-François,

I see in your information on 103P that you were autoguiding. I have not been able to autoguide for more than a few minutes because the autoguider soon finds a nearby star that is much brighter than the comet and then tracks the star. Have you (or any other group members) been successful in autoguiding?

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL
Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

Date:  Sun, 22 Aug 2010 00:14:44 +0000
From:  David Cardeñosa 
Subject:  Image of 103P
Hi!

The last night i imaged the 103P.
After near 2 hours of exposition (56 images x 120") I stacked the 56 images and
i see two weak wave/arcs just behind the comet.
They are weak, but seems real, not artifact.
There are other images showing this?

http://www.flickr.com/photos/dcardenosa/4914083319/

Thanks!

David Cardeñosa

MPC J05 Bootes Obs, Boecillo, Valladolid
http://www.flickr.com/photos/dcardenosa/ 

Date:  Sun, 22 Aug 2010 09:48:10 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  AW: [comets-ml] Image of 103P
Hi David,

I can confirm your observation on images taken at 2010-08-20 UT01:53.

Thanks a lot for your work and congratulation.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/103p_20100820_LS.htm

Clear Skies

Bernhard Haeusler

B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/index.htm

Von: comets-ml@yahoogroups.com [mailto:comets-ml@yahoogroups.com] Im Auftrag
von David Cardeñosa
Gesendet: Sonntag, 22. August 2010 02:15 in Rimpar
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com; comets-ml@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: [comets-ml] Image of 103P

Hi!

The last night i imaged the 103P.
After near 2 hours of exposition (56 images x 120") I stacked the 56 images
and
i see two weak wave/arcs just behind the comet.
They are weak, but seems real, not artifact.
There are other images showing this?

http://www.flickr.com/photos/dcardenosa/4914083319/

Thanks!

David Cardeñosa

MPC J05 Bootes Obs, Boecillo, Valladolid
http://www.flickr.com/photos/dcardenosa/

Date:  Sun, 22 Aug 2010 13:18:28 +0000
From:  David Cardeñosa 
Subject:  Re: [Cometas_Obs] AW: [comets-ml] Image of 103P

to make a followup of the activity.

David

Von:comets-ml@yahoogroups.com [mailto:comets-ml@yahoogroups.com] Im Auftrag von
David Cardeñosa
Gesendet: Sonntag, 22. August 2010 02:15 in Rimpar
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com; comets-ml@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: [comets-ml] Image of 103P

Hi!

The last night i imaged the 103P.
After near 2 hours of exposition (56 images x 120") I stacked the 56 images and
i see two weak wave/arcs just behind the comet.
They are weak, but seems real, not artifact.
There are other images showing this?

http://www.flickr.com/photos/dcardenosa/4914083319/

Thanks!

David Cardeñosa

MPC J05 Bootes Obs, Boecillo, Valladolid
http://www.flickr.com/photos/dcardenosa/

Date:  Sun, 22 Aug 2010 19:11:14 +0200
From:  francois Kugel 
Subject:  10P/Tempel August 22
Hello,

The dust trail of 10P is always present on the images displayed 9x60s
without filter.
A rotational gradient shows two jets shaped antennas PA = 0 and 337
We also suspect (image b & w) the dust tail in PA = 252 just above the
dust trail.
http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/pages/10P.html#100822
C.Rinner, F.Kugel
#A77 - Dauban, France 

Date:  Sun, 22 Aug 2010 21:04:38 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  103P  A Comet with a very bright Future!
I imaged it under terrible conditions, but was still able to capture the comet. My definition of terrible:
 Full moon 63 degrees away
 Local airport reporting 4 miles visibility in haze, so transparency was poor
 The only objects I could see visually were Venus, the Moon, Jupiter and Deneb

But the good news is that the light curve indicates that this comet will reach magnitude 5 by year's end! See http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/0103P/2010.html and scroll down to the Magnitudes Graph. According to my planitarium program, Sky Map Pro, 103P will be well positioned for imaging come year end.

My images and supporting data are here
http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
and I hope you will take a look.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL
Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

Date:  Mon, 23 Aug 2010 01:40:20 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  2P Encke, 22 Aug 2010
Something a little different - comet 2P as a tiny dot in a twilight widefield, taken at 102mm in a piggybacked Canon 400D, 7 x 10 sec, at 08:50, 22 August 2010 UT. Full-frame.

http://tinyurl.com/2e58bo6

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
https://sites.google.com/site/robsastropics/comets

Date:  Tue, 24 Aug 2010 22:03:02 -0000
From:  adastragrl 
Subject:  103P/Hartley 2 images
I've finally updated the Amateur Observers' Program (AOP) website to support the EPOXI mission. And we would love to get your pics of
-- Hartley 2

I will also accept images from some of the other mission targets like
-- Tempel 1
-- Wild 2
-- C-G
-- and asteroid targets Vesta and Ceres
but it might take me a little longer to post them.

Here's the gallery page so far for Hartley 2:
http://aop.astro.umd.edu/gallery/H2_ccd.shtml

Clear Skies!
Elizabeth Warner
EPOXI, AOP webmaster

Subject:  image od 103P/Hartley at September, 2 on B82 Maidbronn
Hi all,

another image of the comet of this morning.
A Larson-Sekanina filter inlay is showing some arcs.
But I am not sure, if they are real (they changed their direction since
August 20 ???).
Maybe Giovanni Sostero has right with his doubts.

Date:  Sun, 05 Sep 2010 13:24:17 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P Hartley 2 sep. 4  LRGB
Thank you Pepe

The green sensitive Chip of the old SXV-H9 ist very good for gas rich comets like 103P.´
At the moment the comet is around 9m5. I think in one month we could find on the images
at least a 25' green coma.

Michael

This is my image from last night

1x300 sec filter green and 3x240 sec UV/IR
RGB 300/300/300 sec bin 1x1

http://www.cometpieces.at/images/phocagallery/103p20100904web.jpg

best regards
Michael Jäger

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 07 Sep 2010 00:24:20 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 103P - 2010/09/06
Thanks John. I am wondering just how big the coma is already. Might be worth an expert to chime in on what to expect as far as a ccd being better to show the outer coma or what equipment will work best.
The equipment:
Tv127is refractor - F5.2 - 660mm - 5"
SBIG ST10 xmei ccd - autoguided with a seperate imager using a TV60is
RGBL - 240sec for RGB and 3x240 sec exp. for the lum using instead a green filter.
All filters are IR/UV block (astrodon 2nd gen filters)
Thanks
Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 07 Sep 2010 02:24:19 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  10P Tempel, 6 Sept 2010
Piggybacked Canon 400D unfiltered, 200mm, 9 x 90 sec, ISO 1600, F/5.6.
Taken at 13:10, 06 Sept 2010 UT; imaged from Bright, Victoria, Australia (36.7S, 147.0E).

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/10P6Sept2010DSScropfullsmall.jpg

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
https://sites.google.com/site/robsastropics/comets

Date:  Tue, 07 Sep 2010 19:13:30 -0000
From:  emartincz 
Subject:  103P near vdB156
Hi.

Yesterday I imaged comet 103P and near I found some nebulae from vdB156 complex. Quite interesting for wide-field! Near comet is galaxy UGC12282. I have combined 10 images on comet nucleus ant then 10 on stars and then combined together.

6.9.2010, 20:45UTC, Canon 30Da, ED80/600, 10x4min ISO1600, GSO mount guiding on stars.

very little frame crop, 25% resize
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/obraz/foto/comet/103p_20100906_orez_m.jpg

crop and 50% resize
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/obraz/foto/comet/103p_20100906_vyrez50p.jpg

Martin Gembec
Czech Republic

Date:  Sat, 11 Sep 2010 16:44:19 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Comet 103P  Getting Noticeably Brighter Every Night!
Comet 103P Hartley 2 in Andromeda is currently at magnitude ~ 9.5.

My images and Seiichi Yoshida's latest light curve data are here
http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
and I hope you will take a look. The light curve promises naked eye magnitude in just a couple of months.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL
Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

Hello.
This is a RGB combination with each channel lasting 1x240 sec. The image is the whole chip reduced to 1650 pix wide or about 1.15 deg of sky wide. N is down and E right. I think Rolando is correct as the coma was not as bright.

Date:  Tue, 14 Sep 2010 15:30:47 -0000
From:  Soulier J-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  176P Linear "MBCs"
Good evening.
I have enjoyed the last week of two consecutive nights in order to
highlight the apparent mouvement 176p Linear (Group MBCS).
I'm at the limit of my instrument, especially with Dec. of -21 °.
PA: 267 °, speed: 0.06 "/ min, stellar background (Nomad / Aladin):
Bmag + / - 21.5
The image comparison:
http://6888comete.free.fr/images/forum/176P20100909.10.jpg

The page on 176p: http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image176PLinearfrance.htm

Have a great week everyone.
SOULIER Jean-François C10/France

Date:  Sun, 19 Sep 2010 18:29:54 -0400
From:  Hap Griffin 
Subject:  Comet 103P/Hartley animation from last night
With one of my friends being the webmaster for the NASA EPOXI comet rendezvous mission to Comet 103P/Hartley in November, I decided to shoot an animation of this brightening comet last night. Even under brilliant moonlight, it was an easy target. Shot with the QSI 583wsg camera through a Planewave 12.5" CDK on an AP1200 mount. Automation via Maxim DL and CCDAutopilot while I slept.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxQiGhfzEgk

I hope you enjoy it.

Hap Griffin
www.imaginginfinity.com

Date:  Tue, 21 Sep 2010 16:17:43 -0000
From:  emartincz 
Subject:  103p 20.9.2010
Hi all.

You have really great images, especially Rolando and Michael! I have only small telescope and DSLR, so I can't take this short time exposures. But with my ED80/600 and Vixen 0,67x reducer I took this image of comet and nebulae (vdB158-LBN 534) and star cluster NGC7686. It was long and terrible day with standing up at 3 am. but today I am satisfied with this image. I hope for ion tail in near future, now I can't find anything like this.

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/obraz/foto/comet/103p/103p_20100920_50p.jpg

20.9.2010, 01:40-02:55 UT, 15x5min, ISO1600
Canon 30D, Celestron ED80 a Vixen 0,67x (402 mm), GSO mount, autoguider

Martin Gembec
Czech Republic

Date:  Wed, 22 Sep 2010 00:50:05 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Hypered Film
Not exactly a comet subject but thought I'd post this. Our refrigerator went bad and when transfering a bunch of food I found a baggie of frozen hypered film. There was Lumicon Kodak Pro 400 - Fuji RD100 - Fuji G800 - Kodak TP2415 and an Elete Chrome 400 slide roll. It has been a lot of years sence this was bought or used and with a week off next month and some time I am thinking of draging out the film SLR. I hope this film is good like they say lasting a long time if frozen the entire time. Anyone try using a product after say 10 years if frozen all the time in a sealed container?
Mike H. 

Date:  Tue, 21 Sep 2010 20:34:52 -0500
From:  Kevin Muenzler 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Hypered Film
Now there's a term I haven't heard in many years!

Yes, your film should be ok...IF it remained sealed and did not get any
moisture or air leakage into the bag. It may not be as good as the day it
was hypered but it should be acceptable, at least as good or better than a
single CCD exposure.

Kevin Muenzler, WB5RUE

Eagle Creek Observatory
http://www.eaglecreekobservatory.org
I believe that all this hype of global warming is going to turn out to be
nothing more than mother nature having a hot flash.

Date:  Wed, 22 Sep 2010 10:26:22 -0500
From:  Kevin Muenzler 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Re: Hypered Film
Generally what "ages" film is heat, oxygen and moisture. If it's in a
sealed container and kept cool (colder the better) film can last for many
years. Newer technologies in film making (since the middle 80's), the
purity and stability of the silver salts (even tones, less fogging), better
stability of the dyes (less color shifting in color film) and better
techniques for producing the plastics have really improved the longevity of
film. Of course with the advent of digital photography and digital movies
innovation in this area has slowed down a bit.

Kevin Muenzler, WB5RUE
Eagle Creek Observatory
http://www.eaglecreekobservatory.org
Mamma don't take my Kodachrome away!
Everything looks worse in black and white...

Subject:  Comet McNaught 2009 R1 moving through sky.
Hello, I am new to this group but put together a animated sequence of comet Mcnaught2009R1 from July. I had used 3 min subs in my Vixen VC200L to catch it moving through the sky. I processed each image in photoshop and then combined using a .gif animator.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Fri, 24 Sep 2010 21:17:33 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Hypered Film
Found some information at lumicon web page. Although I plan to use the film it appears the hypering will not be effective.
Mike H.
Q: How long can I store color hypered film in the freezer?
A: Hypered color film lasts only 1.5-to-2 months in a freezer, since it has a much shorter shelf life than black & white films.
Q: How long can I store hypered TP2415 B&W film in the freezer?
A: TP2415 will remain in a hypered state for 6 months to a year in a freezer. It is durable enough to remain in a hypered state at room temperature for one week.

I hope this film is good like they say lasting a long time if frozen the entire time. Anyone try using a product after say 10 years if frozen all the time in a sealed container?

From:  francois Kugel

Date:  Fri, 01 Oct 2010 15:47:37 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Simple DSLR beats Cooled CCD on comet 103P!
Comet 103P Hartley 2 in Cassiopeia is currently at magnitude 7.6 and brightening rapidly. I've notice a lot of color images of it lately taken with unmodified DSLRs. I decided to compare images taken with a DSLR with that of a cooled CCD camera. I was sure surprised at the results!

Cooled CCD Image
Epsilon E-160 f/3.3 astrograph and Starlight Xpress SXV-H9 binned 2x2; stack of 85 x 90 seconds = 2.1 hours.

DSLR Image
Orion Xpress 80 mm f/6 non-APO and Canon 20D; ISO 800 shooting 8-bit JPGs; 29 x 2 minutes = 0.97 hour.

I was shocked to see the comet's green glow far better displayed in the DSLR 8-bit JPG than the CCD's 16 bit binned image! In fact, when I stripped the luminance from JPG, it displayed the coma better than the 16-bit FIT.

I attribute this strange finding to the following:
1) The comet's glow is in the visible green and the DSLR has peak QE in that region
2) The Sony chip in the SXV-H9 peaks in the near IR and has useful sensitivity out to a micron; but this just brightens the adjacent stars
3) Color, however noisy, affords considerable additional information to the eye-brain visual system

But I'd be glad to hear from others as to their theory. And no need to ask -- the cooled CCD was indeed working properly.

Check it all out yourself at
http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm .

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL
Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm 

Date:  Fri, 01 Oct 2010 17:56:37 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Simple DSLR beats Cooled CCD on comet 103P!
Hello Dennis,
this is rather surprising, since the Sony ICX285AL Exview HAD CCD that fits the SXV-H9, according the specifications, is supposed to peak in the green part of the spectra, and not in the near IR: http://www.starlight-xpress.co.uk/SXV-H9.htm
Bye,
Giovanni Sostero

From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Simple DSLR beats Cooled CCD on comet 103P!
Dennis. Not only is there a difference in what you talk but imaging in the different filters has a big effect. I don't recall a comet showing this much in filter difference with my setup in the past few years. Put together an image showing the rgb filtered images that are unprocessed and of equal length in exposure. Hope the comet grows in size.

Date:  Sat, 02 Oct 2010 00:48:20 -0000
From:  emartincz 
Subject:  103P and Pacman
Hi.

October 1th - Great imaging opportunity and I have clear evening. Incredible. Very nice comet in binocular, especially with small magnification! Coma 25', 7 mag. First image is with Canon 30Dmod and ED80/600+Vixen 0.67x reducer. ISO1600, 4 min. Second is with Canon EF-S 17-85 at 24mm. Comet and Pacman also visible as green and lila dots :-)

http://tinyurl.com/26c3ceg

http://tinyurl.com/2db55n6

Not so saturated and smooth as your CCD images, but what can I do with DSLR ;)

Thanks for your kind words, I'm only "lover of the sky" - nothing about scientific astronomy, only beauty of the skies..

MaG

Date:  Sat, 02 Oct 2010 17:28:55 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Re: dslr and comets
Hi Mike, welcome to the group.

You should be able to get good images of 103P with your setup. I assume your scoope is about f/8. Shooting at ISO 800 you will want exposures in the range of 30 seconds to 2 minutes, depending on your sky conditions. Longer than that an the comet will be traied because is moving fast with respect to the star field.

When you stack the images, you will stack on the comet head. Then the stars will be trailed. You can't have stars and comet sharp at the same time without resorting to complicated techniques.

Here is my setup:
http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
and latest 102P images
http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

The other night I used my Canon 20D and Orion Xpress 80 (not APO) and got nice images at ISO 800 and 2 minutes.

Practice on a star field first -- it is easier!

Clear skies,
Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL
New Images http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

resolution (0.62"/pixel) with excellent seeing (1.0"/1.2").

Gianluca

Date:  Sun, 03 Oct 2010 14:34:14 -0000
From:  msdeprest 
Subject:  Comets 103P Hartley 2 and 10P Tempel 2
Hello Group,
All of you images are absolutely spectacular ... I almost hesitate to share mine. I use MyTelescope.com to do my remote imaging and they don't have the ability for tracking the comets. Also, I am not very good at composing the multiple channels for the color images. So my submitions to this group are gray-scale. Also my processing software is limited in its capabilities.
With that said, you can see my latest images of both comets at:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/28826032@N08/
Thank you
Mark S Deprest

(BTW ... what did I rate on the Humble-Scale?)

Date:  Mon, 04 Oct 2010 01:21:36 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  103P  Easy to image but challenging to observe visually
Comet 103P Hartley 2 in Cassiopeia is currently at magnitude 7.6 and brightening rapidly. It makes an easy and attractive imaging target, especially in color, with its 10 arc minute (or greater) green coma.

But don't expect it to look as bright as a magnitude 7.6 star in the eyepiece! My web page below provides some explanations as well as detailed information on my images and the comet in general. Please take a look.

http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm .

Clear skies and happy comet imaging/observing. 73,

Dennis Persyk N9DP
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL
Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 04 Oct 2010 20:06:04 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] 103P - 2010/10/04
Hello Giovanni. Each time I thought I had learned how to make the stars look
natural with a new software package it always tought me I was not after the
correct path. I droped the software approach and instead went for a hardware
solutiom. Astrodon filters 2nd generation seems to work. Equal amounts of
exposure for each channel produces a good average and allows for ample amounts
of color and shorter exposure times for a good pass of information. The IR/UV
block which all of the filters have including the Lum works good for my setup.
Hope this helps.
Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Hello Giovanni. Each time I thought I had learned how to make the stars look natural with a new software package it always tought me I was not after the correct path. I droped the software approach and instead went for a hardware solutiom. Astrodon filters 2nd generation seems to work. Equal amounts of exposure for each channel produces a good average and allows for ample amounts of color and shorter exposure times for a good pass of information. The IR/UV block which all of the filters have including the Lum works good for my setup. hOPE THIS HELPS.
> Mike H.
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "gvnn64\@...\.it" wrote:
> >
> > Hello Mike, nice image. Wanted to ask which software you are using for the image processing; in particular I'm interested to know which procedure you adopted to obtain such a nice rendition of the background stars color.
> > Thanks,
> > Giovanni
> >
> > > Hello. RGB with the TV60is and ST10 xmei.
> > > Thanks, Mike H.
> > > http://fototime.com/754C5F515BCC4F4/orig.jpg
> > >
> >
> 

Date:  Tue, 05 Oct 2010 03:14:53 -0000
From:  John 
Subject:  Re: 103P  Easy to image but challenging to observe visually
Dennis,

Though comet 103P/Hartley has brightened to around magnitude 6.8, last night it was impossible to find through a pair of 8x50 binoculars and extremely challenging to see through my 5" refractor. In fact, it was so dim that I would have missed it completely had I not centered it in my eyepiece after confirming it with a CCD camera.

Are other observers experiencing similar difficulty?

Best regards,

John

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "dennis_persyk" wrote:
>
> Comet 103P Hartley 2 in Cassiopeia is currently at magnitude 7.6 and brightening rapidly. It makes an easy and attractive imaging target, especially in color, with its 10 arc minute (or greater) green coma.
>
> But don't expect it to look as bright as a magnitude 7.6 star in the eyepiece! My web page below provides some explanations as well as detailed information on my images and the comet in general. Please take a look.
>
> http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm .
>
> Clear skies and happy comet imaging/observing. 73,
>
> Dennis Persyk N9DP
> Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
> Hampshire, IL
> Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm
>

challenging to see through my 5" refractor. In fact, it was so dim that I
would have missed it completely had I not centered it in my eyepiece after

Date:  Tue, 05 Oct 2010 15:36:58 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Re: 103P  Easy to image but challenging to observe visually

Hello John,

The Comets-ML group has two reports. From a dark site one fellow reported seeing in the 8x40 finder scope, 8x42 binocs, 6" APO and 22" f/3.6 dob -- dob was best.

Another obserserver in Spain atop a dark mountain had a good view with 4x30 binocs. I suspect both observers were highly skilled and at very dark sites.

Clear skies,
Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "John" wrote:

Date:  Tue, 05 Oct 2010 16:58:54 -0000
From:  joestieber 
Subject:  Re: 103P  Easy to image but challenging to observe visually


John & Dennis,

I saw 103P/Hartley last Saturday night, 02-October-2010, while working a public star watch at Atsion, New Jersey, a moderately dark forest location that is not much higher than sea level. At 10 pm EDT, it was difficult in my 10x42 binoculars, distinct in my 16x70 binoculars and easy in my 12.5-inch Newtonian. The previous night from my suburban Philadelphia home, I could not see it in the 16x70s or an 80 mm refractor. On both occassions, transparency was very good and there was no moon. Suburban light pollution is a killer.

On the same Saturday night, from a darker location about 12 miles deeper into the forest from where I was, my friend Jerry Lodriguss captured this image of 103P and the Pac-Man nebula:

http://www.astropix.com/HTML/SHOW_DIG/Comet103P-Hartley2.HTM

Joe Stieber

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "dennis_persyk" wrote:

Date:  Tue, 05 Oct 2010 16:58:28 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Re: 103P  Easy to image but challenging to observe visually
I had a hard time pointing at it as I generally try to see a comet in my finder before imaging, but the small core and very diffuse, symmetrical coma make it hard to spot visually. It's best to use accurate coordinates (it's moving fairly quickly) and point and shoot. I finally just took a DSLR shot which made the green coma easy to spot.

My results from 2 Oct. (Saturday):

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2010/1002/index.htm

Dave Kodama

Date:  Wed, 06 Oct 2010 08:51:53 +0800
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 103P Easy to image but challenging to observe visually
Joe and Dennis,

So as always, a dark site wins over light pollution. I did not realize how bad my site has become over the years. I could actually see part of the Milky Way the night I observed Hartley. But apparently, that was not dark enough.

Joe, hats off to Jerry for a superb image. He was one of my inspirations and mentors when I started to get interested once again in imaging. Good to know that he is still catching the light.

Best wishes,

John

Date:  Thu, 07 Oct 2010 18:58:27 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  [Comet-Images] 103P - 6 Oc. 2010
Dear all,

here it is my last image for this comet, imaged at high
resolution (0.62"/pixel) with very good seeing (1.5").

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/103P_Hartley_06october2010.jpg

A 15-deg rotational gradient was also applied.

Best,
Gianluca

Date:  Fri, 08 Oct 2010 09:08:25 +0100
From:  Matt Atkinson 
Subject:  Hartley & double cluster
This is my first post to the group. First of many i hope.

Comet 103/p Hartley 2 and the double cluster
A single 2min exposure, ISO 800, Canon 350d, WO Megrez 72, Heq5 Pro
unguided.

Forgot to take field flattener and reducer and the fog rolled in preventing
a series of subs.

link to image:
http://picasaweb.google.co.uk/lh/photo/N_Ia1bLfgBJIrh1h7Nha9A?feat=directlink

I thank you all with your daily images through the group for providing
inspiration to get out there.

matt

Date:  Sat, 09 Oct 2010 00:50:47 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  103P on oct. 8,
Hello

This is my image from this night, oct. 8 UT 22.00

http://www.cometpieces.at/images/phocagallery/103p20101008web2.jpg

Newton 5,6"/2.9, RGB KAF 6300

Best regards
Michael Jäger 

Date:  Sat, 09 Oct 2010 09:27:13 +0800
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P on oct. 8,

Superb!! Your acquisition and processing techniques are both top rate.

If I may inquire, how long were your sub-exposures and total exposure time?

Best regards,

John

Date:  Sun, 10 Oct 2010 12:22:38 -0000
From:  emartincz 
Subject:  103P 10th Oct.
Hi.

Last night was one of the best this year. I was in dark place, MHV about 6.5 mag. Comet maybe visible naked-eye with averted vision, so it's also around 6.5 mag. Easy visible in 12x50 binoculars, but difficult near or in the towns! So be careful about difficulty of seeing this comet. Here are some images with 80/600mm refractor and 50mm lens on Canon 30Dmod. Nice companion with Heart, Soul and double cluster in Perseus.

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/?p=86

Martin Gembec, CZ 

Date:  Sun, 10 Oct 2010 13:35:05 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  103P near double cluster -  large file
Dear all

i reworked the image from oct. 8, UT 22.00
taken with 5,6"/2.9 and 3x300 sec. (KAF 6300)

To bring out outer coma and the short tail i processed the image with
Astro Art, Maxim DL, Fitswork, Picture Windows Pro 4.0 and Adobe Photoshop. I used Larson-Sekanina-Filter too.

Best regards
Michael Jäger

http://1g388a.bay.livefilestore.com/y1prdndioaJxBSToN0Y1TEPo_tcCmydqAup-noj-lXJdRTjkf7kunnbU1u- 

Date:  Sun, 10 Oct 2010 13:37:08 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  103P large file
please try this one

http://1g388a.bay.livefilestore.com/y1prdndioaJxBSToN0Y1TEPo_tcCmydqAup-noj-lXJdRTjkf7kunnbU1u-YRQeY9GAHtqodzGMF6enzpwR9Bi2exdhTuaXvZQE/103P20101008web.jpg?psid=1 

Date:  Sun, 10 Oct 2010 15:49:46 -0000
From:  Waldemar 
Subject:  103p of 8th september
Hello to group,

back at home we made last weekend a nice astrophoto session.

A quick and dirty shot 7,5° fov LRGB shot of 103p near the doublecluster and some Ha regions.
http://schweifstern.marcel-klein.net/index.php/gallery/category/26-103phartley2.html?tab=0

Waldemar

Date:  Tue, 12 Oct 2010 11:05:52 +0000
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P Hartley October 8th
Absolutely beautiful Chris!

Can you give me some more details about telescope - camera - exposure
length and processing?

I made a monochrome version on October 8 2010, between 21:47:00 UT
and 23:07:48 UT.
http://astropix.nl/103P-CombineFilesExcAvgDDP.jpg
30 x 2 minutes with a clear filter and QSI583 CCD and a Takahashi FSQ106
on a 10Micron mount that was tracking the comet via orbital elements.
Min-Max excluded average and DDP in Images Plus, curves and levels in
Photoshop.

Regards,
Albert van Duin

http://astropix.nl

Subject:  too short
I'm apologize, maybe I'm too much tired. So here is also info about image:
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/sdileni/forum/103p-20101012-dss-31x4min.jpg

31x4min, ISO 1600, ED80/600+Vixen 0,67x, Canon 30Da, GSO mount, autoguider.

Michael - now I saw yours perfect image. Nice tail, the best photo of this comet.

MaG 

Date:  Wed, 13 Oct 2010 18:20:10 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P oct 10  LRGB
Dear all
Thank you for your interest in my images of Comet Hartley.
I think in the next weeks the tail will be brighter. But the thing is
difficult to image processing.
The comet is still in the Milky Way.
Michael

Yahoo! Groups Links 

Date:  Wed, 13 Oct 2010 17:50:27 -0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: 103P Hartley October 8th
Thanks Albert, I found that the only way I could include both objects was to use my Stellarvue SV80s at f/4.4 to yield a 5 degree wide field. If you use 5 minute subs, you can keep the comets nucleus round, and get the max signal to noise on each frame. Stacking the comets nucleus using median did not result in cancellation of all the stars, so I used minimum to stack them directly onto the last frame taken at 4:15. Next I stacked the star registered images directly on to that same last frame using median to combine them. So in reality, all the frames taken during the event were combined simultaneously onto the last frame with the comet closest to the cluster forming a nice isosoles triangle. No cutting, pasting or trickery!

Chris

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Albert van Duin wrote:
>
> Absolutely beautiful Chris!
>
> Can you give me some more details about telescope - camera - exposure
> length and processing?
>
> I made a monochrome version on October 8 â2010, âbetween â21:47:00 UT
> and ââ23:07:48 UT.
> http://astropix.nl/103P-CombineFilesExcAvgDDP.jpg
> 30 x 2 minutes with a clear filter and QSI583 CCD and a Takahashi FSQ106
> on a 10Micron mount that was tracking the comet via orbital elements.
> Min-Max excluded average and DDP in Images Plus, curves and levels in
> Photoshop.
>
> Regards,
> Albert van Duin
>
> http://astropix.nl
>
> Chris Schur wrote:
> > Hi all,
> >
> > I waited until 4:15 am MST to get the closest approach. How does it look to you?
> >
> > http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/hartley100810.html
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Chris Schur
> > Payson, Arizona

the trailed stars so far, but now I know how proceed.

Albert

Date:  Thu, 14 Oct 2010 18:49:11 -0000
From:  Jaicoa 
Subject:  103P/Hartley2 - Oct.13th
Hi Group, On this image the comets nucleus was tracked and as it gets closer the wispy tail is moving counter clk. at this angle (see Oct.10th)same setup. The LRGB was bined at 2x at 4.5minutes duration per channel.
Efrain

At:http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/1050174766/pic/1906177723/view?picmode=&mode=tn&order=ordinal&start=1&count=20&dir=asc

Date:  Fri, 15 Oct 2010 13:27:06 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  103P - 2010/10/15
Hello. 1x120 each RGB - 660mm 5" refractor - F5.2. This comet was really bright in the green and blue. Coma fades and expands equally so there is no telling just how far it goes. This image is croped from original but left a 1x1 bin.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://fototime.com/84BF2E1F07F2C52/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 15 Oct 2010 17:39:42 +0200

Subject:  103P meets open starclusters 15 oct.
Hello,

comet 103P meets open starclusters NGC1513, NGC1545, NGC1528

Images can you see on:

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/menu.html

Erik Bryssinck - Belgium

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 16 Oct 2010 12:16:27 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Re: 103P oct 14 UT 22.38
John

I need Halpha only to bring out the nebulae better.
OIII would be useful for the comets tail. But you would need exposure times more than 10 minutes for a single image.

A lot of green images are good enough.
Next I will post median combined imgages taken with green filter.

Best regards
Michael

Date:  Sat, 16 Oct 2010 20:59:06 -0000
From:  icylander1 
Subject:  Re: 103P oct 14 UT 22.38
Michael,

That is one of the most detailed comet images that I have ever seen.

How did you combine all those images and not show any comet movement? I would have expected to see either star trails or a smudged comet. Did you use several different scopes/cameras at the same time and then combine those images?

I live in Denver with lots of light pollution. For taking images of comets, what would be the best filters to use to get as much comet detail as possible and eliminate as much light pollution as possible at the same time? I have tried a LPF, but it doesn't seem to do much good when trying to get the comet out of the noise. Taking a 5 minute image without a LPF is about the limit before saturation starts to occur with an ST-402 camera. Is there a good website that might explain this to me in good detail.

Thanks for any advice that you may have, clear skies.

Date:  Sun, 17 Oct 2010 12:13:17 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  color image of comet 103P
http://picasaweb.google.it/astroligu/CometeDiRolandoLigustriCASTItalia#5528952939819752690

C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it 

Date:  Sun, 17 Oct 2010 10:19:39 +0000
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  103P Hartley last night
Hi all,

Despite the moonlight I made some images of 103P last night.
Exposures: 4 x 300s each for green, blue and red between 16 october
2010, 21:29:39 UT and 22:34:00 UT with a Takahashi FSQ106 and a
QSI583wsg CCD. The 10Micron mount was tracking the comet automatically
via the orbital elements of the comet. Processing, stacking and DDP in
ImagesPlus 3.82, afterwards curves and levels in Photoshop.

http://astropix.nl/103P-CombineChannelTarget_1DDP2010-10-16.jpg

The dust-tail was quite prominent in the red channel.

Regards,
Albert van Duin

http://astropix.nl 

Date:  Sun, 17 Oct 2010 12:41:29 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] color image of comet 103P
I like it

Michael

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 17 Oct 2010 12:46:16 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 103P oct 14 UT 22.38
Sorry. I know no site.
One thing.
To make best comet pictures you need a fast and very good optics
and a sensitive large format chip.To observe the faint coma and tail
you need a very dark sky.
I work with one telescope and camera and RGB filters from Astronomik from a dark mountain location.

Michael

----- Original Message -----
From: icylander1
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, October 16, 2010 10:59 PM

> ===============================
> C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
> 

Date:  Sun, 17 Oct 2010 14:12:40 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 103P oct 14 UT 22.38
John

The scope is a home made Newton 140/ff-4.0 combined with a 2" ASA corrector/reducer 0.73. I had no image
CCD - http://www.nova-ccd.de/
I use a older model with KAF 6300 (28x18mm chip)

Michael

----- Original Message -----
From: John Nassr
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, October 17, 2010 1:53 PM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 103P oct 14 UT 22.38

Michael,

What aperture and speed is your scope? What camera do you use? Do you have a picture of your scope that you can share?

John

--- On Sun, 10/17/10, Michael Jaeger wrote:

From: Michael Jaeger
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 103P oct 14 UT 22.38
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sunday, October 17, 2010, 10:46 AM

Sorry. I know no site.

One thing.

To make best comet pictures you need a fast and very good optics

and a sensitive large format chip.To observe the faint coma and tail

you need a very dark sky.

I work with one telescope and camera and RGB filters from Astronomik from a dark mountain location.

Michael

----- Original Message -----

From: icylander1

To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

Sent: Saturday, October 16, 2010 10:59 PM

Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: 103P oct 14 UT 22.38

Michael,

That is one of the most detailed comet images that I have ever seen.

How did you combine all those images and not show any comet movement? I would have expected to see either star trails or a smudged comet. Did you use several different scopes/cameras at the same time and then combine those images?

I live in Denver with lots of light pollution. For taking images of comets, what would be the best filters to use to get as much comet detail as possible and eliminate as much light pollution as possible at the same time? I have tried a LPF, but it doesn't seem to do much good when trying to get the comet out of the noise. Taking a 5 minute image without a LPF is about the limit before saturation starts to occur with an ST-402 camera. Is there a good website that might explain this to me in good detail.

Thanks for any advice that you may have, clear skies.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "schmidtcamera2500" wrote:

>

> John

>

> I need Halpha only to bring out the nebulae better.

> OIII would be useful for the comets tail. But you would need exposure times more than 10 minutes for a single image.

>

> A lot of green images are good enough.

> Next I will post median combined imgages taken with green filter.

>

> Best regards

> Michael

>

>

>

Date:  Sun, 17 Oct 2010 05:35:20 -0700
From:  Efrain Morales 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P Hartley last night
Hi Albert, Simply a Beaut!. This method (Traditional) not only shows the beautiful inner/outer structures of the comet but with very good scientific values also, A super job welldone my friend looking forward to see more :).
Efrain

--- On Sun, 10/17/10, Albert van Duin wrote:

From: Albert van Duin
Subject: [Comet-Images] 103P Hartley last night
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, ImagesPlus@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sunday, October 17, 2010, 7:19 AM

Hi all,

Despite the moonlight I made some images of 103P last night.
Exposures: 4 x 300s each for green, blue and red between 16 ‎october
‎2010, 21:29:39 UT and ‏‎22:34:00 UT with a Takahashi FSQ106 and a
QSI583wsg CCD. The 10Micron mount was tracking the comet automatically
via the orbital elements of the comet. Processing, stacking and DDP in
ImagesPlus 3.82, afterwards curves and levels in Photoshop.

http://astropix.nl/103P-CombineChannelTarget_1DDP2010-10-16.jpg

The dust-tail was quite prominent in the red channel.

Regards,
Albert van Duin

http://astropix.nl

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Subject:  new image of comet 103P
hello

here my new image of comet 103P from last night (16 okt. 2010)
http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/menu.html

______________________________________________

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck - Belgium

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/
BRIXIIS privat observatory - MPC code: B96
coordinates: 418.6 E - 519.8 N
______________________________________________
C.A.R.A. - Cometary ARchive for Amateur astronomers -
http://www.cara-project.org
VVS - Vereniging voor Sterrenkunde - http://www.vvs.be
Antares - http://www.astrobasis.be/ 

Date:  Sun, 17 Oct 2010 16:17:33 +0000
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P Hartley last night
Thanks Efrain,

I like the pictures where the comet motion has been frozen, but I tend
to loose a lot of the comet detail in the process.
That's why I stay with my old techniques....

You can find some of my older comet-work on my website http://astropix.nl

Regards,
Albert

Date:  Sun, 17 Oct 2010 18:24:27 +0200
From:  "GUSTAVOMULER@telefonica.net" 
Subject:  images 103P small jet NE two days. 15 / 16 - 10 - 2010 J47
specially in LS processing and MCM is easy to see this artifact / structure.
pictures are different days and images from different shots.
on the 15th, where more than 300 pics, all shows this structures,.
images 15-10-2010

http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/103p/103-101015-J47.jpg

Date:  Mon, 18 Oct 2010 17:26:01 +0100
From:  joan manel bullon i lahuerta 
Subject:  Re: [Cometas_Obs] medidas visuales de cometas
Hola Carles.

Yo también he aprovechado la transparencia de esta madrugada para observar el cometa 103P Hartley 2, es por ello que acompaño una foto que he hecho a 3 minutos de exposición con un pequeño refractor de 80/400 mm desde Aras de los Olmos. Saludos.

Joanma.

--- El lun, 18/10/10, Carlos Labordena Barceló escribió:

De: Carlos Labordena Barceló
Asunto: [Cometas_Obs] medidas visuales de cometas
Para: "Cometas_Obs" , "Observadores_cometas"
Fecha: lunes, 18 de octubre, 2010 17:49

Hola

Esta noche , aprovechando que hacía una noche muy transparente y la Luna faltaba poco para esconderse, me subí a Culla (Castellón), a 900m de altura.

El cielo estaba muy oscuro, con una calidad de cielo de 21:38, que como el 103P transitaba por esa zona me dió una visión excelente del cometa. Hacía unos 6ºC pero con el fuerte viento la sensación era desagradable. Primeramente le di un vistazo al 10P, antes de que bajase demasiado su altitud. A continuación ataqué el 103P. Se veía fácilmente a simple vista,
midiendo sin dificultad su magnitud, con bastantes estrellas de comparaión a distancia conveniente.
Después lo hice con el pequeño refractor desmontable, una mezcla de bricolage y de arqueoastronomía (tiene mas de 40 años el objetivo). Se apreciaba perfectamente, ganado más brillo y mas coma.Después utilicé los prismáticos 11 x 80, que son los que me dieron la visión más bonita, apreciando un aspecto fantasmagórico, "hólmico", con la parte central de la coma más brillante y alargada. Después con el catadióptrico de 200mm la cola se podía destacar perfectamente, embebida dentro de la coma.

Saludos

Carlos Labordena
Castellón - V03

clabordena2@yahoo.com
clabordena@gmail.com
www.astrosurf.com/clabordena

10P          2010 10 18.10069 10.1    3M 3           SC 50 X 200  V03
103P         2010 10 18.10764 04.8   60M 3           R 4 X 30     V03
103P         2010 10 18.11111 05.0   60M 2           SV           V03
103P         2010 10 18.11944 05.3   50M 4   20M     SC 50 X 200  V03

Date:  Tue, 19 Oct 2010 05:08:07 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  103P Hartley, 18 Oct 2010
Starting to rise again in southern skies - drove out to a site with better northern horizon this morning but was beaten by rising mist. Only got 2 noisy 90 sec subs, but salvaged something from them. Link is to a page with two crops, and the full frame.

https://sites.google.com/site/robsastropics/comets/comet-103p-hartley

Rob Kaufman
Bright, Vic Australia (36.7S, 147.0E) 

Date:  Tue, 19 Oct 2010 16:51:47 -0000
From:  emartincz 
Subject:  103P in Auriga
Hi,

my last photo before full Moon, Oct. 19th before dawn (around 3:15 UT). Poor weather conditions, foggy only zenith quite good (LM around 5.7 mag), comet visible very poor with naked eye. I have used my Canon 30D modified camera with Super Takumar 1,4/50 lens (at f4). This image is from median combined images (12x3min at 1600ISO).

25%
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/obraz/foto/comet/103p/103p-20101019-50mm-12x3min_m.jpg

50%
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/obraz/foto/comet/103p/103p-20101019-50mm-12x3min.jpg

Martin Gembec

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 23 Oct 2010 10:08:54 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Last color image of comet 103P
>Rolando,
>As usual, superb and a treat to behold....especially with a bright moon! The tail is
>well captured too with colors nicely saturated and >separated.
>Best wishes,

Hi John,
one thing I've learned in recent years, particularly using the telescopes remotely is
that the quality of the sky makes a tremendous difference on the final quality of the
photo ! The site in New Mexico is amazing !
one other thing, I was able to photograph the comet when it was high in the sky,
which here from Italy I had to get up at dawn ... :-)))
Last thing: we are talking about picture appearance, which is also working with PS :
I equalizes up to the original image to see what objects are visible, how big the
comet and its tail, then processes the image with PS

a wonderful thing I've learned in 15 years of use of the CCD, is that with these
systems, compared to film, gradients may be removed easily due to the Moon

best regards
Rolando

Dear friends,

night is important.

el cierre completo de la Luna en el horizonte y el crepúsculo principio.

Muchas gracias por sus imágenes magníficas. Me gustan todas.

Date:  Sun, 24 Oct 2010 21:11:05 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  development of 103P/Hartley from October, 9 to October, 22
Hi all,

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/103p_20101009.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/103p_20101010.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/103p_20101011.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/103p_20101012.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/103p_20101013.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/103p_20101022.htm

Overview on:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/103p.htm

The magnitudes are evolving from 10.45 mag at October,9 to 9.41 mag at
October,22 in a 60 x 60 arc seconds box.
Replace the image of October, 22 from my last email, please. Thanks to Luis
for his hint.

Clear skies and Saludos
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "emartincz" wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
> my last photo before full Moon, Oct. 19th before dawn (around 3:15 UT). Poor weather conditions, foggy only zenith quite good (LM around 5.7 mag), comet visible very poor with naked eye. I have used my Canon 30D modified camera with Super Takumar 1,4/50 lens (at f4). This image is from median combined images (12x3min at 1600ISO).

From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image and animation of C/2009 Y1 (Catalina)
Hi,

the 75% Moon very close to 103P/Hartley? - a good opportunity for image
processing of another comet.
a Luna el 75% muy cerca de 103P/Hartley? - Una buena oportunidad para el
procesamiento de imágenes de otro cometa.
la Luna il 75% molto vicino a 103P/Hartley? - Una buona occasione per
l'elaborazione delle immagini di un'altra cometa.
Der 75%-Mond sehr nahe an 103P/Hartley? - Eine gute Gelegenheit für die
Bildverarbeitung eines anderen Kometen.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2009y1_20101021.htm
animation of 60 images included.
animación de 60 imágenes incluidas.
animazione di 60 immagini incluse.
Animation von 60 Bildern enthalten.

Date:  Thu, 04 Nov 2010 19:59:23 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  C/2010V1 Ephemerides
Hello Group,

I'd like to image newly-discovered C/2010V1 tomorrow night from my Midwest USA site. I've been unsuccessful in downloading ephemerides from the Harvard site -- the request just hangs. Where can I get the ephemerides?

Thanks!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Fri, 05 Nov 2010 21:09:41 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2010V1 Ephemerides
Hi Dennis,

I updated my GUIDE 8.0 ephemerides and get the following – based on a New Zealand location – but being so bright you should easily see it anyhow...

Ikeya-Murakami (C/2010 V1)
Date RA declination r delta mag Elong Speed PA
---- -- ----------- - ----- --- ----- ------ -----
6 Nov 2010 12h39m12.03s -02 34' 59.5" 1.7309 2.4792 12.4 32.8 109.08 117.8
7 Nov 2010 12h41m45.41s -02 55' 17.2" 1.7327 2.4770 12.4 33.1 108.81 117.8
8 Nov 2010 12h44m18.49s -03 15' 31.0" 1.7346 2.4748 12.4 33.3 108.54 117.7
9 Nov 2010 12h46m51.26s -03 35' 40.6" 1.7366 2.4727 12.4 33.6 108.25 117.7
10 Nov 2010 12h49m23.70s -03 55' 45.9" 1.7387 2.4706 12.4 33.9 107.95 117.7
11 Nov 2010 12h51m55.82s -04 15' 46.7" 1.7409 2.4685 12.4 34.2 107.65 117.7
12 Nov 2010 12h54m27.61s -04 35' 42.7" 1.7432 2.4665 12.4 34.5 107.33 117.6

21 Nov 2010 13h16m58.32s -07 31' 03.2" 1.7679 2.4499 12.4 37.3 104.16 117.2

28 Nov 2010 13h34m08.54s -09 41' 31.2" 1.7921 2.4386 12.5 39.6 101.30 116.8
29 Nov 2010 13h36m34.16s -09 59' 40.9" 1.7959 2.4370 12.5 39.9 100.87 116.7

1 Dec 2010 13h41m24.17s -10 35' 37.5" 1.8037 2.4340 12.5 40.6 99.97 116.5

Date:  Fri, 05 Nov 2010 11:32:44 -0600
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  C/2010 V1 and Saturn
Hi everyone,

It appears that the comet will be located slightly less than a degree from
Saturn on November 8 and will pass just over a degree south of the planet a
day later -- an interesting conjunction both visually and for imaging.

Incidentally, my m1 measurement that's reported on IAUC 9176 is probably a
bit of an underestimate, since the comet is right in the middle of a strong
zodiacal light.

And, yes, there will be a "Countdown" announcement sometime in the
not-too-distant future . . .

Sincerely,

Alan 

Date:  Fri, 05 Nov 2010 19:11:45 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley

has been uploaded:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2010v1_20101105_mpm.jpg

Martin

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html 

Date:  Sat, 06 Nov 2010 09:07:43 +1100
From:  Ian Musgrave & Peta O'Donohue 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Noisy GRAS image of Ikeya-Murakami
G'Day All

Martin Mobberley wrote:
> A very noisy image of C/2010 V1, in strong twilight,
> has been uploaded:
>
> http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2010v1_20101105_mpm.jpg

[applause] This comet will be dashed hard to image because it is so close
to the horizon, and that's a good picture (how did Ernesto Guido and
Giovanni Soster get such a good image of 2010 V1 with the GRAS scopes). I
was going to try with G14, but it lost tracking :-(

Cheers! Ian

Ian Musgrave, Peta ODonohue, Jack, Mikey and Andy

Date:  Sat, 06 Nov 2010 09:58:40 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  Re: Noisy GRAS image of Ikeya-Murakami
Hi Ian,

They were using GRAS 004 when I was using GRAS 002.
I think every 'scope was pointing at the comet!
My original image was horrendous as the flat fielding
wasn't any good in such strong twilight. It took a long time
to fix.
The GRAS walls are at least 20 degrees high and so by
the time I imaged it the Sun was -11 degrees.
I guess GRAS 004 had a v. good view over the furthest
wall when the Sun was <-12 degrees and that the
GRAS 004 flat fields were recent and good quality......

Regards,
Martin

>G'Day All

Martin Mobberley wrote:
> A very noisy image of C/2010 V1, in strong twilight,
> has been uploaded:
>
> http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2010v1_20101105_mpm.jpg

to the horizon, and that's a good picture (how did Ernesto Guido and
Giovanni Soster get such a good image of 2010 V1 with the GRAS scopes). I
was going to try with G14, but it lost tracking :-(

Cheers! Ian<

HI all,

Very nicely placed in Canis Minor, the comet will soon dissapear below our northerly horizons. So I wanted to make a big effort to get out and shoot it well. Here is the result:

thanks for looking,

Chris

Date:  Mon, 08 Nov 2010 05:42:26 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Hartley 4 Nov.
Very nice Rik. That's what I am seeing with R filter. The tail was protruding
more noticeably this morning as you show. I notice that in R filter the single
shots I take, show that the central condensation is elongated. V filter images
show almost round central and condensation. This must have something to do with
the difference in gas versus dust. I am studying it. If we could see the comet's
spectra, perhaps that would make the situation more clear.

I noticed that longer exposures/stack by Rolando Ligustri a couple of days
ago showed a very faint ion tail but still not very distinct as in other recent
bright comets that have passed by over past year.

Just wish I knew more about how to explain these things. I'm still so much of a
naive beginner. I just keep studying and observing.

Charles (H47)

________________________________
From: Rik Hill
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Cc: Chris Schur

-Rik

Rolando Ligustri

C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it

Date:  Mon, 08 Nov 2010 14:21:29 -0700
From:  Rik Hill 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Hartley 4 Nov.
Right Charles, and I should have mentioned that it's a broadband R image.

-Rik

On 11/8/2010 6:42 AM, Charles Bell wrote:
>
> Very nice Rik. That's what I am seeing with R filter. The tail was
> protruding
> more noticeably this morning as you show. I notice that in R filter
> the single
> shots I take, show that the central condensation is elongated. V
> filter images
> show almost round central and condensation. This must have something
> to do with
> the difference in gas versus dust. I am studying it. If we could see
> the comet's
> spectra, perhaps that would make the situation more clear.
>
> I noticed that longer exposures/stack by Rolando Ligustri a couple of
> days
> ago showed a very faint ion tail but still not very distinct as in
> other recent
> bright comets that have passed by over past year.
>
> Just wish I knew more about how to explain these things. I'm still so
> much of a
> naive beginner. I just keep studying and observing.
>
> Charles (H47)
>
> ________________________________
> From: Rik Hill >
> To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
> Cc: Chris Schur >
> Sent: Mon, November 8, 2010 1:00:53 AM
> Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Hartley 4 Nov.

> coadd of 4 images:
>
> http://www.lpl.arizona.edu/~rhill/comets10/Hartley10.html
>
>
> Enjoy,
>
> -Rik

Date:  Tue, 09 Nov 2010 07:02:26 +0000
From:  Μanos Kardasis 
Subject:  103P 7,November 2010
Hello,

here is my image:

http://astroforum.gr/forum/album_pic.php?pic_id=3575

from suburban location the mag estimation is

103P/Hartley
Nov. 07.2 , m1= 5.5, Dia=7', DC=4 (Manos Kardasis, Glyfada-Athens,Greece, C11 telescope)

Date:  Tue, 09 Nov 2010 05:44:59 -0600
From:  "Dr. D. T. Durig" 
Subject:  [Comet-Images] C/2010 V1 in outburst 11 07 UT


I have posted a couple of images of Comet Ikeya-Murakami C/2010 V1 from 2010
11 07 UT, just before local dawn, on my comet observation page:

http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view_c.php

One is an animation of 20 x two minute exposures and shows the approaching
daylight.

The other is a false color stack of 5 x two minutes that shows the inner and
outer coma structures.

There was a particularly bright guide star nearby that morning so the
tracking was better than other nights that I tried.

Dr. Doug Durig

Cordell-Lorenz Observatory

The University of the South

Sewanee TN

>and I understand what you mean by difficult conditions. Very nice, as always you do
>some great work!

the problem is that for two mornings out of 4 came the clouds :-(

however at the end I succeeded and I am happy with the result :-)))

Date:  Sun, 14 Nov 2010 19:57:04 -0000
From:  Comet-Images-owner@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  Group member question and reminder to members
Does anyone know who this person is?

Vahid Tayebi

It's not clear whether this person is having problems with his account or is a potential spam-bot. He has attempted to post empty replies to messages and has not replied to private requests to clarify his status. The membership is being cancelled now because of this. If you know this person, please let them know what happened and invite him to re-join the group.

REMINDER: If you recommend someone join this group, we welcome that, but please let them know that they MUST include a comment indicating that they are indeed a human who is interested in our group's subject. If a request to join is received with no comment or an ambiguous one such as "Hi, I'd like to join your group", they are allowed to join but posts from them are automatically held until it's clear that they are coming from a legitimate member.

Thank you to all for your cooperation.

Date:  Thu, 18 Nov 2010 08:16:59 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  AW: [comets-ml] possible fragmentation of 236P/LINEAR
Dear Seiichi,

no sign of fragmentation on my image of November, 1 2010 down to 20 mag (120
min. exp.)

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/236p_20101101.htm

Clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler

B82 Maidbronn

Von: comets-ml@yahoogroups.com [mailto:comets-ml@yahoogroups.com] Im Auftrag
von Seiichi Yoshida
Gesendet: Sonntag, 14. November 2010 09:15 in Rimpar
An: comets-ml@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: [comets-ml] possible fragmentation of 236P/LINEAR

Dear colleagues,

Jean-Francois Soulier reported me the possible fragmentation of
236P/LINEAR. Two possible fragments were detected on Oct. 30 and
Nov. 4.

Jean-Francois Soulier's images:
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image236PLinearfrance.htm

Toru Yusa and Hidetaka Sato confirmed the possible fragmentation on
Nov. 11 and Nov. 9 respectively.

Toru Yusa's image:
http://space.geocities.jp/yusastar77/#236P_101111

Hidetaka Sato's image:
http://www.aerith.net/tmp/G04-101108-0236P-01-04.png

Best regards,

--
Seiichi Yoshida
comet@aerith.net
http://www.aerith.net/

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Sun, 28 Nov 2010 15:45:27 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  103P between M46 & M47
13:15, 28 Nov 2010 UT - piggybacked Canon 400D, 105mm, 6 x 120 sec at ISO 1600, F/4.5.
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/103P28Nov201013-15UTcrop.jpg

Full frame:
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/103P28Nov201013-15UTffsm.jpg

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
https://sites.google.com/site/robsastropics/comets 

Date:  Sun, 28 Nov 2010 19:25:30 -0500
From:  Hap Griffin 
Subject:  Comet 103P between M46 and M47 last night

Here is a quick image of Comet 103P Hartley 2 gliding between M46 and M47 last night. The moon had just risen before I realized that the comet was in this favorable location so the image is somewhat washed out and had a strong gradient. I kept the exposures short since I had to shoot in RGB and keep streaking minimal. Upon further consideration today, I could have shot more images and used some fancy processing to work on the stars and comet separately and then re-combine to keep streaking down, but this image is a “true” one...such as it is.
http://www.astrophotogallery.org/imaging-infinityccd/p6705-comet-103p-hartley-2-in-m46-2f47.html
Hap Griffin
www.machunter.org
www.imaginginfinity.com

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 29 Nov 2010 18:30:02 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet  P/Hartley and M47
Hi,

please find attached (if it’s not stripped) an image of P/Hartley (103P) that I took on Saturday night (2010 Nov 27 14h UT). It was taken with a 350D DSLR through a 20cm f4.6 Vixen Newtonian. 12 x 2 minute @ 800 ISO. The star cluster on the right is M47 in Puppis.

John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287

Date:  Mon, 29 Nov 2010 10:01:14 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  Re: Comet  P/Hartley and M47
Unfortunately it has been stripped John. There is a solution to this - attachments in emailed posts can be allowed on Yahoo groups. In groups where this function is available, there is an "Attachments" sub-link under "Messages" in the menu on the LHS of the group Home Page. I notice there isn't one here. The group moderator should be able to add this facility. Considering this group is all about images, maybe it should be added??

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman

From:  sabiajohn 
Subject:  Re: Comet P/Hartley and M47
If I enter the Yahoo Groups I will see the attached image. However I am set to receive Daily Digest in my email account. Attachments are not in email, a pointer is. That pointer is broken upon wrapping.

1 of 1 Photo(s) http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/attachments/folder/247633947/item/list

comet103p-hartley-20cm@f4,6-350d-12x2min-800asa-101127-drummond-web.JPG

Attempt to fix the line wrapped pointer results in the error.

HTTP Status 404 - /photoapp/jsp/errors/file_not_found.jsp
type Status report

message /photoapp/jsp/errors/file_not_found.jsp

description The requested resource (/photoapp/jsp/errors/file_not_found.jsp) is not available.

John D Sabia

Date:  Tue, 30 Nov 2010 15:23:42 +0100
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Comet P/Hartley and M47
Why so difficult? Upload your pictures to any of the countless free image
depositories on the web and mail the link here! This has also the
advantage that the pictures are visible linkable for everyone and can get
the wide distribution they deserve. For example, in
http://cosmos4u.blogspot.com I regularly link to the best images of
current comets - yours could be there, too ...

Dan 

Date:  Tue, 30 Nov 2010 15:23:47 +0100
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Comet P/Hartley and M47
Why so difficult? Upload your pictures to any of the countless free image
depositories on the web and mail the link here! This has also the
advantage that the pictures are visible linkable for everyone and can get
the wide distribution they deserve. For example, in
http://cosmos4u.blogspot.com I regularly link to the best images of
current comets - yours could be there, too ...

Dan 

Date:  Tue, 30 Nov 2010 17:24:37 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Comet P/Hartley and M47
Hello. The possible choices ar very limited here. Here are the 3 possible solutions

Store on site (exclude from emails)
Include in emails (exclude from site)
Exclude from site and emails

As you can see both ways are not a possibility so I will leave as is and members can visit the messages, attachments to view the images. I will of course moderate these images for violations. I do invite all members to use the free storage space. If it becomes too full at some point members are ask to delete images and if this is not enough management will need to create space for newer images. So far this has not been close to a problem
Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 30 Nov 2010 23:39:47 +0100
From:  Josef Müller 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P - 46P Nov. 29
Am 30.11.2010 19:59, schrieb francois Kugel:
>
> Hello!
>
> http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/images/cometes_img/103P/103P-10112922-450sfull.jpg
> Regards,
> Francois Kugel
> #A77
>
Bon soir Francois,
une photo magnifique de 103P/Hartly! Depuis des mois je suis votre liste
et j'en admire les resultats!
La comte est -22 degr - c'est pour moi, 50 degr N, assez bas!
Ce qui m'tonne c'est que tu cris "103P - 46P" - au premier moment je
me suis attendu 46P/Wirtanen!
Mais celle-ci est 27,1 mag! Incroyable! Non, c'est M46 open cluster,
un amas Messier!
Ce qui m'a tonn ensuite c'est l'object au NE de M46.
J'aurais d mieux apprendre par coeur mes objects messier et les plus
importants objets ngc!
NGC 2438 - une nebuleuse plantaire assez importante, 10,1 mag!
J'ai donc appris, qu'il faut toujours continuer complter ce qu'on
connat! Merci!
Dommage - tu aurais presque pu atteindre M47!
J'attends des nuits claires
A bientt
Josef Mueller #A21 
Date:  Wed, 01 Dec 2010 09:12:51 +0800
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P - 46P Nov. 29

A beautiful image! What scope and camera did you use?

Best wishes,

John

Date:  Thu, 02 Dec 2010 06:22:55 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re: Comet P/Hartley and M47
Hi,

I’m not sure what the problem is as I belong to another Yahoo group – ‘New Zealand Astronomers’ and we all just attach our photos to the messages and everyone – including me who just gets the daily digest can see them (there’s a thumbnail image that gets opened in Internet Explorer when clicked. The URL of the image is -

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nzastronomers/attachments/folder/1846294177/item/1782022031/view

which shows that the image is stored in the attachments folder of NZA.

Simple to see and very simple to upload.

Cheers

John Drummond

Re: Comet P/Hartley and M47
Posted by: "dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de" dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de skyweek
Tue Nov 30, 2010 6:23 am (PST)

Why so difficult? Upload your pictures to any of the countless free image
depositories on the web and mail the link here! This has also the
advantage that the pictures are visible linkable for everyone and can get
the wide distribution they deserve. For example, in
http://cosmos4u.blogspot.com I regularly link to the best images of
current comets - yours could be there, too ...

Dan

Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz

Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287
Date:  Wed, 01 Dec 2010 18:51:37 +0100
From:  francois Kugel 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 103P - 46P Nov. 29

Francois

Le 30/11/2010 23:39, Josef Mller a crit :
>
> Am 30.11.2010 19:59, schrieb francois Kugel:
>
>> Hello!
>>
>> http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/images/cometes_img/103P/103P-10112922-450sfull.jpg
>> Regards,
>> Francois Kugel
>> #A77
>>
> Bon soir Francois,
> une photo magnifique de 103P/Hartly! Depuis des mois je suis votre
> liste et j'en admire les resultats!
> La comte est -22 degr - c'est pour moi, 50 degr N, assez bas!
> Ce qui m'tonne c'est que tu cris "103P - 46P" - au premier moment
> je me suis attendu 46P/Wirtanen!
> Mais celle-ci est 27,1 mag! Incroyable! Non, c'est M46 open cluster,
> un amas Messier!
> Ce qui m'a tonn ensuite c'est l'object au NE de M46.
> J'aurais d mieux apprendre par coeur mes objects messier et les plus
> importants objets ngc!
> NGC 2438 - une nebuleuse plantaire assez importante, 10,1 mag!
> J'ai donc appris, qu'il faut toujours continuer complter ce qu'on
> connat! Merci!
> Dommage - tu aurais presque pu atteindre M47!
> J'attends des nuits claires
> A bientt
> Josef Mueller #A21
>

> the wide distribution they deserve. For example, in

> current comets - yours could be there, too ...

Date:  Mon, 06 Dec 2010 02:04:05 -0000
From:  John 
Subject:  Hartley, Dec 5, 2010
Hi,

Here is a 20 minute exposure taken last night of Comet Hartley 103P. I used a 5" refractor and 16HR cooled camera with a 28x35 arc minutes field of view. The comet is still quite bright and with an extensive coma.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/8968253/pic/896517882/view?picmode=large&mode=tn&order=ordinal&start=1&dir=asc

John 

Date:  Mon, 06 Dec 2010 12:20:56 -0000
From:  adastragrl 
Subject:  103P/Hartley images
Reminder that if you have images of comet 103P/Hartley, to share them also at http://aop.astro.umd.edu/gallery/logbook.shtml

If you happen to also use Facebook, you can also share them at www.facebook.com/EPOXI

Please note that technically I don't have funding to work on that site so I'm having a student (as part of a school project) help me as well as working on it when I have some free time. So, if you have already sent images, it may take a little while for them to show up, but that we are getting them posted.

Clear Skies!
Elizabeth Warner
EPOXI, AOP webmaster
warnerem [at] astro.umd.edu

Date:  Tue, 07 Dec 2010 05:29:32 -0600
From:  "Dr. D. T. Durig" 
Subject:  P/2010 V1 very diffuse, no nucleus, no tail


After weeks of clouds and moonlight, I finally got a chance to try
to get an image of Comet Ikeya-Murakami P/2010 V1 again. But I had a hard
time finding it in my images. According to the MPC Dates of Last Observation
page for comets, it was 9.2 total mag on 11/24. But I could only get
something around 16 mag now and I could not identify a distinct nucleus.
There was just a diffuse blur with no discernable tail. It was rather gusty
and I could not find a guide star, but stacking images really didn't help
much. Anyone else tried for this comet recently?

Dr. D. T. Durig
Cordell-Lorenz Observatory OBS CODE 850
The University of the South
Sewanee, TN

Date:  Wed, 08 Dec 2010 22:59:12 -0000
From:  josephbrimacombe 
Subject:  240P/Neat passes close to theta gemini
Hi All

Attached is a link to a widefield image of Comet 240P/Neat passing close to the star theta gemini on Dec 7 between 04h55m and 05h55m UT. The image is a single 1 hr exposure at F/5 with an image scale of 3.5 asec/px
http://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/5243563978/
There is also an animation: http://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/5242674723/

Date:  Thu, 09 Dec 2010 06:48:00 -0600
From:  "Dr. D. T. Durig" 
Subject:  RE: {MPML} Comet Ikeya-Murakami P/2010 V1 is very diffuse with no tail


I had much better conditions this morning and got 25 x 2 minute images. No
wind, low 20s, VERY clear skies, good guide star, about as good as it gets
around here. But still a very diffuse comet, much dimmer at mag about 17.5,
with essentially no tail and it was hard to find a nucleus to measure, but I
did get something to measure by stacking 10 minutes worth of images. Clearly
this comet is fading rapidly. I know it passed perihelion about 2 months ago
and it should be fading, but this seems to be fading a lot faster than it
should. It must have been in outburst when it was discovered and is now
loosing its activity quickly. I never heard from anyone else about their
images but I did notice in the recent MPEC that others were reporting it as
significantly dimmer. Anyone have any comments at all ???

Dr. D. T. Durig
Cordell-Lorenz Observatory OBS CODE 850
The University of the South
Sewanee, TN 

Date:  Fri, 10 Dec 2010 13:21:36 +0100
From:  Fredrik Broms 
Subject:  Re: @ D.Durig; Comet Ikeya-Murakami is very diffuse...
Just a quick reply to D.T.Durig on recent experiences of C/2010 V1
Ikeya-Murakami.

After a long period with cloudy weather up here in Northern Norway,
yesterday morning (Dec 9) finally offered a good clear view (and my first
opportunity to try to image Ikeya-Murakami since Nov 07 and Nov 10 when it
was very easy to see both visually and on images (even visable on a single
30 sec test exposure I did with Nikon D3 DSLR).

07 Nov 2010: http://kometen.fg-vds.de/pix/2010V1/2010V1_07112010.htm
10 Nov 2010: http://kometen.fg-vds.de/pix/2010V1/2010V1_10112010.htm

So, yesterday morning (9 Dec), I started imaging from "comet-rise" until
dawn and having polar night up here now gave me about 1 hour of total
imaging time.

The result? I am actually not sure if I was able to capture it at all. I do
not think so. I have to do some more post-processing of the stack, but so
far I have failed to record it and was surprised that I couldn`t see a trace
of a comet in such a long exposure and relatively good conditions.

It seems that the comet has been fading surprisingly quick after it`s rather
spectacular outburst.

Clear and dark skies, Fredrik Broms
___________________________

Northern Lights Photography
- imaging made green-
Fredrik Broms
www.fredrik_broms.fotosidan.se
http://nordlysfoto.blogspot.com/
____________________________

Date:  Wed, 15 Dec 2010 10:18:37 -0000
From:  Soulier J-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  00596 Scheila

Hello everyone.

The "coma" changes ?
With a G. R 20 °, I get 5 jets. Including two obvious and well
spoken.
But with this kind of tool, I'd be cautious for a categorical statement
to the other 3.
PA : 20, 190, 240, 280 and 340.
His m2 seems not to move at around 13.8 with 8 "opening.
Diam. coma + / - 2 '.
Speed to 0.26 "/ min.

And unfiltered images 37X60s report :
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image596france.htm


Sincerely.

SOULIER Jean-François

Date:  Sun, 19 Dec 2010 07:28:17 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Comet 103P/Hartley in the Milky Way
Another shot of Comet 103P (see the small green ball in the lower left corner of the shot) taken on the morning of 14 Dec.

http://astrocamera.net/2010/1214/index.htm

Dave

Subject:  For sale
Hello. I have decided to sell my scope and cameras. Haven't thought about price so if your interested contact me in private for price talk. TV127is just back from the factory for optics aleighn. Perfect shape. ST10 xmei ccd - ST2000 first run camera - (CFW8) I think 5 filter SBIG color filter wheel with Astrodon 2nd generation filters including RGB and an Ha. Fits both cameras. Will answer questions as long as these pieces are not sold. Both cameras work as new. I won't answer any post on this board about this as I should not have posted here anyway but wanted members first go at my equipment.
